ReviewList.Text: I read over a hundred books a year. All genres. I don't give a 5 rating lightly. For me a 4 can be something great. A 5 is something that is great and stays with me long after I read it. This will stay with me. I was there with the characters and in that silo from the first few pages. I could feel every emotion, frustration, and even the physical sensation of being dizzy and tired from the trips through the silo. The story kept building and I wanted to know everything and couldn't put it down. Truly superior writing and storytelling. I can honestly say it was one of the best things I've ever read and makes what I thought were some pretty good books seem terrible now. . .I'm talking to you Hunger Games. I look forward to the day when this has its own movie too because it surely deserves it.

I enjoyed reading the Wool Omnibus books.  The characters were interesting and it kept me guessing all the time, which I love!  The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was the author's propensity for long drawn out descriptions of settings and/or characters' actions.  All I need to know, for instance, is that the character put her knife away, after some fumbling.  Don't need a detailed joint by joint movement of the knife into the sheath.  These common digressions into painful detail slowed the book noticeably.  After a while, I could sense one coming and would skim it.  The plot line and characters more than make up for this and keep Wool an all but engrossing read.

I know I'm in the minority here and that's ok. I enjoyed the originality of this story, the strong female heroine, as well as finally getting to the end and receiving a thoroughly satisfying closure. What I didn't enjoy was the laborious effort of getting from point A to point C while having to trudge through so many unnecessary pages of text. I felt that this would have been a higher star review for me if it was done more concisely in two rather than five parts and a lot of redundancies, tutorials, and other such over explanations were cut out. I felt as if I were literally dragging myself through thick mud while reading the majority of this book and the only thing pushing me along to finish was shear stubbornness of not giving up.

I have been struggling for years to be able to concentrate long enough to finish a book. It's been 7 years since and it has been extremely frustrating. Then I stumbled upon Wool. Wool broke my dry spell. I couldn't put it down. I couldn't not finish it. It was amazing. I liked this book so much I bought the hardcover version so I can have it on a shelf and be reminded of how much I enjoyed this book.

Reading Wool 1-5 was, for me, one of the greatest reading experiences I've had in the last 5 years.  These books are truly remarkable.  As compelling a reading experience as the finest Stephen King, yet sci-fi to the core.  Mr. Howey has three great strengths that he employs in these 4 novellas and 1 short story:  1)  Great story-telling.  You feel like you are in the silo with these people.  2)  Characters you can relate to.  For me this is key.  Many sci-fi authors fall short in this area by having wooden, stock or boilerplate characters to complement their stories.  Not so in Wool 1-5.  I was riveted by the story and often stayed up into the early morning hours to read "just one more" chapter.  3)  Leaving you wanting more.  Luckily for me, Wool 1-5 left me wanting more.  There are many plotlines left to flesh out and areas to discover.  In fact, if there's one thing that impresses me most about Wool 1-5 it's that the author was able to make such compelling reading out of such a - on the surface at least - simple premise.  People living inside a concrete tube doesn't have to be compelling reading.  Yet thanks to Mr. Howey's unique ability to craft a compelling HUMAN story, Wool 1-5 rises far above the ranks of most sci-fi.  To me, these are modern day classics.  Awesome.  Simply awesome.  5/5

Interesting enough to read, however did not live up to my expectations.  The reviews I read were so good on this that it made me excited, however was let down by a lack of action and adventure.  I just finished reading the hunger games series and was expecting Wool omnibus to be better, but it's not.  There are several parts that are slow and dull.  It's worth reading, but not better written than the hunger games.

I won't lie... it's SO difficult for me to find books that I love.  And by love, I mean REALLY get into and can't put down.  Very few books have captivated me in this way, but the WOOL series was one of them.  I read the first one after downloading a sample of the omnibus for my Kindle.  What can I say?  I was hooked.  I read the remaining 4 books within a week, relishing every moment, but dreading the progress bar moving closer and closer to the finish line.  I didn't expect to be so captivated by these characters.  Most science fiction is so focused on the story that character development goes out the window.  Not so with this series, and I am so thankful for that.  This will definitely be a series to re-read.  I have already started 3 friends on it, and I know that they will enjoy it as much as I have.

I must be missing something here.  This is one of the most boring books I have attempted to read.  After chapter 10 I started skipping ahead 10 pages, then 20, then 30....  It's like watching a TV soap opera.  You can tune is a month later and realize nothing has been missed.  I could have cared less about the characters.  They groan on about their emotions and plights that could have been easily avoided.  When the female hero meets her destiny at the end I thought "finally".

I picked this up based on the other reviews here and the fact that the Ombnibus is generously priced at only $5 for Kindle.  No regrets, and frankly the $5 price is a steal for us readers.  The story becomes more engrossing volume by volume, even though the focus of each segment often moves to new or different characters.  I did feel the action and tension slipped oh-so-slightly at the end, but that doesn't change the fact that Howey's done a great job of fleshing out interesting protagonists and antagonists, as well as a "new world" that's fascinating to explore (level by level, as it were).  I certainly hope there's more to come from the world of Wool.

When I bought Wool, the first book in the series, it was because I was looking for a quick and inexpensive read.  The ratings were high, the story looked interesting, and the price was right.  After finishing all the books (one immediately after another at breakneck speed) I can state unequivocally that I would pay any amount for future books in this series.  The concept is intriguing and the characters living in this world are portrayed vividly and honestly.  There are no "placeholder" characters in the series, everyone is fleshed out and has believable and consistent motivations.  Another thing that should be noted about these books is the lack of spelling and grammatical mistakes.  I know it's a trivial point, but I enjoy a book so much more when I'm not cringing at every other page.  Don't pass up this opportunity to get all the books together.  Once you start, you're not going to stop!

Great to find a new author & series that captures the attention!  I downloaded the first part of the series, started reading & couldn't stop until I finished it, then immediately downloaded the next four parts!  It took me two days to finish it all only because I had to go to work!!  I can't wait for part six to come out so I can jump back into this dystopian world full of unique characters & ideas.  Please keep writing Mr. Howey!  I am now following you on twitter!

I'm honestly shocked by the good reviews of this omnibus book. Its honestly one of the worst books I've read in years. The first couple 'novels' in the omnibus are painfully slow and more like short story format than a novel. The whole thing is painfully obvious once you get a short way into the series and simply not very believable. I guess if you like plodding, simplistic, post-apocalyptic stories this is for you. If you like complex and subtle novels I'd stay far away.

It is so rewarding to find an author that exceeds your expectations! I usually download samples onto my Kindle because I've bought far too many books that sounded interesting only to be disappointed.  Wool captivated me from the beginning.  I read through all five books in two days. This author has that rare talent of allowing the reader to feel like a participent of the story. He also leaves you conflicted as to 'what is the right thing to do'?  Great characters that you can identify with, fascinating plot, well written, and yes there most be another sequel!

Just finished reading and wish there was more.  I went to the author's website and understand there is more to come.  Good news, indeed.  Anyone who wants a well-written story that will suck you into a new and frightening world, here it is.  I can see great things for the author.  What a movie these books would make.  Stop reading the reviews and get yourself a copy.

This book I found by word of mouth from a friend who was reading it and enjoyed it. I bought each of these separately but I'm reviewing the 1-5 bundle as I have just finished book five. I truly love reading good stories and this is one of the better books I've read in quite some time. It was hard to put down and now that I have finished book five I just want more. The characters are very real, and the plot often seems to be predictable then turns in ways you don't expect which is truly a merit of great art in writing. It is a very believable, very real and very well woven story. Worth every penny.

Wool was free this weekend but I knew I couldn't read just one so I bought the omnibus.  WOW!  I couldn't put it down -- I carried my iPad around all day so I could keep on reading.  When I finished I bought 3 more of Hugh Howey's books.  This was truly one of the best books I've read in a long time.  Well written (and thankfully well edited), this spiral into the silo is both touching and heart-pounding.
I read this omnibus edition in two days and I loved it! The characters were well developed and the story was original and had a lot of twists. I would really like to see more of this series.

I recently bought these to read on my e-reader. They are good enough that I want the hard copy too! I am a huge reader of sci-fi, often going through over 3 books a week. It isn't very common to have a book suck me in so much that I couldn't put down until I was completely finished with it, but this one did. I can't wait to read more of the story!

I read a lot of Science Fiction but mostly space opera, the more aliens, space battles, and starships the better. I also rarely write reviews. I was waiting for the release of some more books in a couple of series I have been reading and thought I would read this to kill time while I waited. I read the reviews and thought what the heck, this isn't really my thing but this should last a couple of weeks. It lasted two days! The plot grabs you, the characters are amazing and it keeps you on the edge of your seat in anticipation! The only problem I had with this book was putting it down! It's worth every penny spent and then some! I really really hope Mr. Howey has plans to continue this series! A must read!!

I've been working my way through the discounted and free Kindle ebooks available, and thought I'd take a chance on this well-reviewed and very inexpensive piece. I'm glad I did. It's easily one of the better pieces of apocalyptic fiction I've read -- character-driven, deeper than it at first appears, and generally well-paced -- and possesses just the right combination of reflective inner narrative and visceral (but not particularly graphic) action to make the whole thing hard to put down until it's finished. I can't describe too much about the plot without touching on some major spoilers, so I'll just end with a strong recommendation. "Wool" is one of the best books -- print or otherwise -- that I've read this year, and this has actually been a pretty good year for books. At under five dollars, this should be an instant buy.

I first read the first Wool story and I couldn't put it down.  The Omnibus was mentioned in it's reviews and I jumped at the chance.  Like the first one, each story is well written, the character development captures the reader, it is truly exceptional writing.  It is rare to find writing of this quality.
Fantastic story about a bleak future in a world gone wrong. Great depth of character in the heroine and I can't wait to see what happens next.

I have a kindle and was sifting through titles when "Wool" just leapt off the screen. What an intriguing choice of a title, and it certainly piqued my curiosity. I'm so glad I did. I love reading science fiction books about the underground world, be it caves or subways... and now I can add silos! It's funny, when I was young my favorite thing to draw was a cross section of a house inside a hill, complete with many levels and rooms. This series really spoke to that part of me! Anyway, there are many reviews to be read about the content of this series, so all I want to say (besides you should read this series!) is that I loaned "Wool" to my teenage son who is an aspiring science fiction writer. I told him that "Wool" is written by a fledgling writer whose books are solely distributed by Kindle, and it seems to be working really well! So nice to know that individuals authors can get their literature to their audience without any middle man markups and publisher headaches! A great inspiration for my son!

I LOVE THESE BOOKS. After reading the first I was thrilled to find there was a sequel, and then another, leading to a whole series! Reading these took me on an emotional ride, rooting for Juliette, Lucas and all of Mechanical! Definitely one of my new favorite series, and I'm going to recommend them to everyone!! I'M IN LOVE WITH the story, and can't wait for more to come! :)

The Wool series of short stories is quite simply one of the best and most immersive books I've ever read.  My only complaint was that the end of the story arrived and I was so immersed in the characters that I was heartbroken to find out there wasn't another page to turn to.  Hugh Howey has an incredible talent, and that is to feed you gradual bits of info without seeming to tease you intentionally.  You genuinely feel like you're in the Silo looking over the characters' shoulders.  You never know more than they do about where they came from, and he keeps you guessing right up until the end about where they're going.  If you are at all consider buying this book, please do it...you won't be disappointed!

I'm writing this review for the "Wool Omnibus" even though I read all 5 seperately. When I stumbled across "Wool 1", I was instantly hooked. I quickly downloaded #2-5 and read them like an addict needing a "fix"! These books are that good. Well paced and beautifully written. The first installment may be a bit slow and even confusing at times, but the thrill ride picks up steam in #2 and never lets up through #5. I'm now waiting not-so-patiently for "Wool 6"! I have no idea why these books are priced as low as they are, but they are worth many times more in pure reading enjoyment. In lieu of "Wool 6", I just downloaded "Half Way Home" to get my Hugh Howey fix. I predict a bright future for Mr. Howey (unlike the denizens of the Silos).

I stumbled across the anthology and picked it up on my Kindle.  I couldn't put it down once I started reading.  Not that I'm some literary expert, but it reminded me of Alas, Babylon which is one of my favorite post-apocalyptic books.  It's definitely worth checking out.  I hope to see lots more from Hugh Howey!  Keep up the great work sir!

What a great story! I could not put this "book" down but after sleepless nights I finished all five and days after still had the story in my mind. This yarn sure does stays with you well after you've finished it.  I think that has something to do with the sense of the underlying claustrophobic-ness of the silo: dark and kind of oppressive but well worth the read. Thanks hugh. Can we  have more Wool?

I have read this series individually and consider it to be among my all-time favorites. In fact I believe it will go down as one of my top-ten reads. Well written with complete plots and great character development, I recommend this to anyone who likes to escape to an alternate reality.

The book is just plain boring. Based on all of the glowing reviews, I kept reading it, believing I possess some personal character defect that was preventing me from recognizing Wool as a truly great work of fiction. I got past Book 1, then 2, then 3 (because Wool is subdivided into smaller books), waiting for Juliette to take her place as the central character. I knew that was a turning point of the novel. But when she did, no point turned. The book was still plodding, slow, and dull. At page 135, I gave up on the book and went on with my life. For those reviewers who truly enjoyed the book, I applaud you. For those of you who didn't but published fake positive reviews, shame on you, because I purchased both Wool and Shift, and have wasted my money based on said reviews.

A friend of mine told me he was reading this series of books called "WOOL", and told me how much he enjoyed them. So I said well I will get a sample for my kindle fire and see what the fuss was about. I have to say that its been a while since I read a book that just grabbed my attention like WOOL did. I read the sample and was instantly hooked. So I decided that if the first book was any indication on what all 5 were like then i better just get all 5 because I'm gonna be longing to read more! Excellent read, if you are a fan of sci-fi novels then you will love WOOL!

You want something special to read during vacation? This book is it! It's not your run of the mill story for a home read! My husband read it first and recommended it to me. (I'm hijacking his account here.) It's been a long time since I've been this enthralled with a plot--so different and imaginative. I couldn't put it down! I started reading it on the plane and opted for three days (until I was done) to sit by the pool, "book" in hand rather than go out of the resort sightseeing. I had to know what happened next!! You feel like you are part of the story and in that silo with them. What an adventure! Just when I thought I had the plot figured out (which I always try to do before the story is over) it surprised me, again and again! Wow! Can't wait for more Wool! Please hurry with the next installment Mr. Howley!! I will have to schedule another vacation to read it!

Well, it seems that every other reviewer has already described what a great read this book really is. What else is there to say? Simply put, this series of novellas is a roller coaster. It isn't just any roller coaster, it's the best one at the park. If I try to explain what it's like to ride that roller coaster, the words just come out an excitedly jumbled mess. The adrenaline gets pumping and I no longer make sense, but you can see the pure excitement on my face. Don't like roller coasters? Then it's a water slide. Hate water slides? Then it's one of the best meals you've ever eaten. If you don't like roller coasters, or water slides, or food, don't read this book. If you're human, then I highly recommend it. Be one of the cool people who gets to experience something great!
The worst part about this book is that I finished it and now I have to go find another book to read.  I don't WANT to find another book to read.  I want to stay in the World of Wool.

Writers of science and speculative fiction have a huge responsibility. They gaze back and forth in time, peering through the dimensional veils, and bring back what they've seen on their journey. Good writers have the ability to crack the walls of our mind, letting in the fresh air and light of the unknown. Hugh Howey is one of those writers. Howey has created a crowded, lonely and lovely world. The writing puts you right there, a voyeur on every landing, all the way to the Down Deep. This story is, quite simply, brilliant. There is love and tragedy, despair and enlightenment, and best of all, delicious redemption. Enter the Silo, watch your step... and your back.

This book is amazing.  Hugh Howley knits a post-apocalyptic world that rises up around the reader like the walls of the silo in which it takes place.  If you've been looking for a new and well-written scifi fix, you'll find it in Wool.  You'll know the characters, you'll see the world they live in, hear its noises and smell its scents.  You'll read this book from one end to the other without putting it down, wondering how you'll make it through the next day with the sleep you've lost, haunted by the echo of the world of Wool in your mind.  This book is a must-read.

This is a well written novel, better than many of the "low cost" kindle books. I'm glad I read the combined version as I would have hated waiting for installments to find out what happened to favorite characters. I don't want to spoil anything for other readers but I certainly hope that the author finds a way to put in more HOPE for the human race in any future stories (apparently planned) for other silos.  Optimism for the future and the expectation of amazing encounters is what drew me to science fiction.  Wool reminds me of the Hunger Games series which I read to its conclusion because it is a gripping story. However, I don't think I would ever want to put myself through either story again! In contrast, I re-read my favorite books many times.

Like you, I had never heard of this book or its author but it was so highly rated and sounded so interesting and unique, I had to download it to my kindle.  I read many books in many different genres and I am always looking for the next great story.  The Wool Omnibus delivered, exceeding all my expectations.  You enter an underground world that is immediately unique and fantastical but also very recognizable in the everyday questions and struggles faced by the Silo's citizens. I tore through the first 4 books and then started forcing myself to slow down in a vain effort to stave off ever finishing book 5 and reaching the end of the story. The only silver lining is that this author has more books and I plan on reading them all as I continue to hope for Wool 6. If you are a reader, then trust a fellow reader and buy this book.

Once every few years I stumble upon Book that renews my excitement for a good story teller. Hugh Howey's Wool series is one of those lucky finds. After a few chapters of Wool 1, I immediately downloaded the Omnibus edition. These are great stories with characters I hope to meet again in the future. I think Hugh has allot to bring to the Sc Fi genera and look forward to more. I encourage everyone to spend a few dollars, less than that Starbucks coffee you purchased this morning. You will be more than satisfied.
Not a dull moment.  It's rare that I find a book I put down only because I'm too tired to see straight.  If you like the free section, you'll love the rest.

There is nothing I could say that hasn't been said by many of my fellow reviewers of Hugh Howey's "Wool", so I'll keep it brief: My mind went into the silo and the air locks closed shut behind me. I was in there, experiencing it, smelling it, tasting it. I think my legs even hurt from going all the way to the down deep and back up-top several times over. I can see why Ridley Scott wants to make a movie out of it. It already is one. Hugh Howey created a world desperate and hopeful at once, where both lie so close to each other, I found myself thinking that it was a perfect rendition of the world we live in now (I'm wondering when the iPhone screen size will become 2 by 8 inches). I loved the double twists about what's real and what's fabricated; the sheer physical depth of the silo mirroring the depth of despair and hope of its occupants. And as the silo itself, the story goes deeper and deeper with every round, every chapter. Great work, Hugh!

To begin, I do not read books of this genre often. Possibly, most probably, because of their tendency to be extremely negative and downright depressing in nature.  Nor am I so easily impressed as to actually write reviews often, however, with that said, I am absolutely compelled to share with others my joyous feelings that this is one of the best-written, most finely and expertly crafted books in any genre that I have ever had the extreme pleasure of reading!  From the set-up to the very last words it excels any lofty expectations I had from reading the reviews of others. I hope those reading this who are debating the purchase will heed my plea for them to just begin reading it.  Afterward is a no brainer as I'm certain you will agree within a very few pages.  God!, I do so hope this is made into a movie by someone competent who is as appreciative as I am for its genius!  Keep up the great writing Hugh Howey!  We need more a.s.a.p.!

I wanted to read this book after going through some glowing reviews. I am not suggesting that this is a bad book but can confidently say that it is way too overrated. The premise is good and would have been a good reading if it were 200 to 250 pages long. unfortunately it is a 500 pager and the remaining 250 pages just detail the difficulty of climbing stairs up and down. I understand that the author needs to provide an idea about the size of the silo and all by detailing the difficulty of going up and down the various levels in the silo. However, there was no reason to do it once every 5 pages. I probably skipped 40 % of the pages with out really losing track of the plot.

I took a chance on the omnibus edition on my Kindle and wound up inhaling the Omnibus edition in just a couple of days.I'm going to be getting more by this author. I've been burned by self-published stuff, but this find makes it worth it. The good editing and readability just makes it even more of a treat!
Haven't read something this good in a long time.  I was sad to see it come to an end.  I am hungering for more!

Even if you've read it all, prepare to have your socks knocked clean off. Howey delivers a powerful story, rife with intrigue and causing an excellent degree of introspection. Moral ambiguity is rampant, seasoning memorable and engaging characters. The dialogue is magnificent, and the storyline will leave you gasping, groaning, and cheering. Fancy spending some tome on the edge of your seat, unable to put your book down? Then read this brilliant and refreshing series, and let Mr.  Howey take the post-apocalyptic genre for an absolute joyride.

I've read some bad books in my time.  Space operas that wander around without a goal, fantasy epics that spend a chapter describing food stains, but this series of short stories is without a doubt the slowest I have ever read.  I gave it two stars because it reminded me so much of Fallout's story-line that i enjoyed the nostalgia brought on by remembering that game series.

The most positive things I can say about the Wool Omnibus are that the prose is decent (though never thrilling or beautiful) and the basic concept (the "world of wool" so to speak) is fairly interesting (though never quite intriguing). I had a feeling the author had spent countless hours imagining details and working out all the connections. Even so, I read Wool 1-4 and then decided I owed it to myself to dispense with reading Wool #5--which (unless there are a number of appendices) comprises nearly half of the Omnibus, so even at its bargain price, I felt I'd wasted my money. Wool #1 is the most rewarding of the five and the only one that can stand alone. The other four are all dovetailed installments, each one skirting around the same central mystery and evidently inching toward some climactic revelation--but the movement within each installment is very slow, in part because each one introduces a new main character (entailing a fresh round of back-to-square-one exposition and re-orientation); and in part because the prose bogs down in too many picayune moments. It's possible I missed a marvelous payoff at the end, but getting there wasn't worth the effort for me: I was simply never captivated, didn't really care how it all comes together. The weaknesses of the Wool Omnibus are numerous, but the slow pacing is the deal breaker: by the fourth installment I was only reading the first sentence of each paragraph, just getting through as quickly as possible (more like reading homework than reading for pleasure) and sad to say I could still follow the narrative quite easily that way, so again, not that much is really happening, and there aren't any key insights along the way. The second major flaw is the interchangeability of major characters: there are a lot of them, and they all have nearly identical personalities, the same ernest and stalwart virtues, despite their differing bodies and different roles in wool society. There are simply too many heroes here, yet they all seem like clones.

I am an avid reader of science fiction.  I can't remember the last time I read such a unique, engaging and well written story.  Hugh Howey's rich characters carry you through a world that is unveiled one layer at a time.  The suspense and need to turn the next page (or click the next page button) matches the intensity of the story.  Gone are the days of ending a book with the feeling of having read the same story before.  No more settling for the overall lack of originality in the science fiction and fantasy genres.  Howey is an author to follow carefully.  I can't wait to read more of his work, and I especially can't wait to return to the world of Wool.  He claims to read all of his Amazon reviews, so let me say directly to the author, "More, please."

After the first section of this book, I was already predicting some of the key plot points and twists.  Perhaps I've read one too many dystopian novels, but the inevitable escape of the protagonist, rebellion and war were just way too predictable.  The characters are given sides very conspicuously (e.g., "This is the bad guy", "This is the good guy").  On the plus side, if you enjoy detailed descriptions of people walking, climbing stairs, fixing generators, sitting, eating, etc... this book is for you - but they make this book twice as long as it needs to be.  There's enough content here for a novella, but I feel the author was reaching more for page count than content.

I purchased WOOL on a whim and loved it.  It does a great job pulling the reader in and keeping them hooked for the whole book.  I immediately bought and read Shift after this to keep the story going.

This has to be one of the best series I have read in the past 5 yrs.  The content is so unique, the pace is astonishing, and it keeps you wondering "what is out there?!" One answer leads to more mind bending questions - a ride unlike any other.

Every time one of my friends asks me what they should read next, I say this series. The writing is top-notch and the story is great. I have read the Wool series and the Shift series that follows and have been impressed the whole time. You will not regret buying this book. It's so good I would buy it again just to give the author my continued support.

As an aspiring writer (translated - have a million stories running through my head but no writing experience) I must admit I downloaded this book for the sheer purpose of seeing how a successful self/Kindle-published book reads. Not being a huge fan of science-fiction, I truly did not expect to love this story as much as I do! I've read all 7 parts and can't wait until the 8th is released! The plot is very compelling and I felt an immediate connection with the main characters (and without giving anything away will say I'm excited to have hear that one will finally return in part 8!) This book was extremely well written and edited and I have recommended it to all of my friends. I love that each book reveals a little bit more insight into how this civilization has become what it is. Something inside me just longs for them to go "outside"...yes, I said it! ;) I hope we get to experience that at some point in this amazing series!

I am a voracious reader, devouring four or five books a week.  I bought this Omnibus edition for my Kindle because it was the Kindle Deal of the Day, it sounded like an interesting story, and the reviews were great.  It takes a lot for me to step up and write a review.  There are a lot of good books in the world and it isn't often that I find one I feel compelled to recommend to everyone.  Great story, great writing, and it would make a great movie. I was so invested in the characters that I find myself wondering what they are doing now since I left them.  Of course I had to buy book six and I hope there are a dozen more. Thanks for a terrific story, Mr. Howey.  You have moved to my list of must read authors.

Wool has the potential to be a movie and,a study work for mankind's sociological,philosophical and ethical beliefs,now, and in the future. As crazy as it sounds development of this theme could create the new Hunger Games. This should not be thought of only as science fiction but a thought provoking adventure novel. I anxiously await Wool 6-10.
Hugh is the newest addition to my favorite authors.  Technically excellent writing, he also has a gift for character development and setting.  I'm eagerly looking forward to more!

I am enthusiastically heaping more praise on the gigantic pile for this book. I downloaded it after being enthralled by Howey's Kindle Single, "The Plagiarist" (also fantastic, check it out). Simply put, you don't get this many five star reviews (and fan fiction!) without something truly special. Not wildly science-fiction, this story is accessible to all and easily haunting. There are layers of story, literally and figuratively, but is not in any way overbearing. Read it-- I've told friends about it and no fewer than three have been hooked. Enjoy!

I'm sure other reviews are more eloquent than this one, but I had to write after finishing Wool.  Absolutely amazing story, amazing writing, gripping all the way through.  A must read.  I'm so glad I gave this a go, and look forward to whatever comes next from Hugh Howey.  Can't recommend this book enough.  If you like Sci-Fi at all, you won't be disappointed.  Rarely do I come across a story this well told.

When a Kindle Book has over 1500 reviews and all all laudatory, that gets my attention.  I have had a love/hate relationship with my Kindle since I got it for Christmas in 2011.  I am never quite certain if I can wrap my head around the fact I am reading an actual book.  WOOL presented a chance to read something good, perhaps great, that was not available in the store.  I have read a ton of Science Fiction, and a bevy of stories dealing with a post-apocalyptic world.  This is simply the best.  For me, characterization is key. I am looking for a multi-dimensional story that places great characters in challenging situations forcing them to become more than they are ... forcing them to become great.  WOOL does it in spades.  Very well-written, it will tear at your heart strings and will keep you turning pages, or touching the screen, or hitting a button, or doing whatever it is you do with your Kindle.  Thanks Hugh. I am going to try out some of your other stuff.
These were awesome stories. Great for sci-fi fans and anybody who likes a good story. The author should be paid more for his work. We need more stories!!!!!

I could not put this book down. Fantastic writing, awesome story and great character development. This probably has been the best series of books I have read this summer. Actually, this might be the first 5 star review I have given. I'm looking forward to reading more of this author's books. I have a feeling that in the near future we will be paying more than $5.99 for five books from Mr. Howey. Please keepthe story going...I can't get enough.

I just stayed up way too late reading this book, and I have no regrets.  The stories come in perfect, bite-sized pieces, even though I couldn't put it down after starting the first one.  The plot and writing are both excellent, and I related to the characters.  The only thought I had after turning the last page was, More Please!

I meant to save this book for my vacation. However, I made the mistake of reading the first paragraph. Now I have to find something else to read on vacation, and I know it won't compare to this little gem. I kept reading until I finished just a few minutes ago and was determined to write a review, which I seldom do. I want everyone to know this author deserves kudos, lots of them. It takes quite a bit of skill to make you love a character in just a few paragraphs and even more skill to make you rush through those paragraphs to find out what happens next. I am anxiously awaiting more of WOOL.

way better than the hunger games trilogy and i LOVED that series.  Right up there with Enders Game, my all time favorite from 20 years ago.  Luckily it's Mothers day so i can get number six read.  Hugh, I hope you get paid what you are worth some day.

Could there possibly be anything better then buying a book by an author you've never heard of simply because the price is great and so are the reviews only to discover that the story is fantastic? The good guys are good and the bad guy, well, he's just doing his job. The story flows along well and leaves lots of room for more stories to follow. Right now am gonna head on over and take a look at "Molly Fyde".
Interesting and thought provoking; this book is unusual, well written and absorbing. It deserves the 5 stars - my teenage daughter is also reading and enjoying it now.
Just blew through this.  Well deserving of it's Hugo nomination, which is where I came across it.  Get it - it's really good.
Buy them all because you will not be able to stop reading once you start! Can't wait to read more by the author.

This book started out OK and kept my interest. However, as it progressed I feel like it droned on about all the minutia and small details and derailing from the main story. It did this so much that I got tired of reading for days about their trip down the stairwell. I couldn't bring myself to finish the book as it quickly lost my interest.

I was lucky enough to come along to this series when they were all collected into the Omnibus. Such interesting concepts that sucked you in and make you think about your own self-made "silos". The style is sophisticated enough for an adult, yet not so overwhelming as to scare away a well-read teenager. Keep it up Hugh. You have a gift!

I have not been so engrossed by a story since I first read Dune. The characters are rich and complex.  The story vibrantly dark. The suspense is intoxicating. Clear your schedule. You will not be able to put these books down, until your done.

This was a suprise that hooked me in from the beggining. It was fantastic to watch the story and characters develop as each book came along. Juliette, in particular, was a strong intelligent character. I loved this world. It was so thought provoking. I thought most questions were pretty well answered and the ending, whilst open for a continuing story, tied things up well. Worth the read.

The characters were interesting.  But just the slow progress between the levels lost my interest.  I wanted to know what happened so I was interested.  But there were pages and pages of little activity.  So I skipped through areas.
I do not have much to add I just wanted to be yet another 5 star addition so more and more people fall in love with the world of Wool like I did.

This book is just amazing... I borrowed it from the Kindle library (Yay Prime!) for free, but I would easily recommend buying it if you don't have a Prime membership.  I read it until midnight last night, and when I woke up at 6 for work I read another couple of chapters before even jumping in the shower.  That's how this book is.  Free up some time, people, because you're going to be reading like some Wool-Addicted crackhead.
seriously can't rate it highly enough... one of the most interesting and engaging science fiction / post apocalyptic books I've ever read.
I really dont think I can say anything that everyone else hasnt already said. Outstanding. Definitly deserves the 5 star average that got me to buy it.

Another great find. I actually read Wool a while back and although I thought it was great it left me feeling very depressed. I just recently came across the Wool Omnibus Edition and read some of the reviews and thought I would give the other stories a chance to lift my spirits of the Silo world. 17 hours later I had finished and felt myself in a state of awe. I have been reading many dystopian books but this one is a stand out for sure. I highly recommend it to anyone who wanting a dystopian adventure.
Beautifully written. Plot and character development top notch.  From the first page to the very last - just couldn't put it down.  Best in class!!!!!

Reading them all separately, I don't think all five deserve five stars, but as a whole it's an unbelievable story.  The original Wool is so good that I was slightly let down by Wool 2, but it picks back up and ends up being an amazing overall story.  Wool 2 even becomes more enjoyable as it becomes just a section of the overall story.  An absolute must-read, not just for the sci-fi fans, but for everyone ages 12 and up!  I hope the omnibus never receives anything less than a five star!

As an avid SciFi reader for over forty years, I've read them all - Campbell, Heinlein, Asimov, Clarke, and more recently Card and Sawyer.  The Wool stories rank right up there with the very best.  Right from the start you don't feel like you're reading a fantasy or fiction story, you are transported to a new reality with a real world, real characters, and real situations.  And it is not a story you are done with when you finish - it stays with you, I'm guessing for a very long time.  I highly recommend reading Wool whether you are a SciFi fan or just want an excellent story.  You will not be disappointed! As I write this review there are 47 out of 47 five-star reviews; there is good reason for that!

I had never heard of Wool until it was recommended by Amazon (the first time i actually liked an Amazon recommendation.) The story was fun to read; intriguing; well-written with no pretense.  I'm sucked in now.  Thank you.  I just wish I didn't read it so fast, so please write more!

After many years of not reading I decided its time to get back into it.  Wool 1-5 was a perfect way to get back into it and reminded me of why I love to read.  Even if your not a huge fan of science fiction this series portays the struggles that can happen in any society.  Some where in the middle the books seems to lose a little steam, but it continues to build til the end.  A great read from an author I would have never tried if it not been for Amazon.  I am now looking at the authors other titles.
very good.  The more I read the more I liked this book.  Also love a bargain and this is a great book at any price.
Too good to put down. Great story with characters you will know and care about.  All ratings are 5 stars - this is correct information.

I found Wool by accident by browsing through books on Amazon.  It had good reviews and the price was right so I bought it.  Now, after reading all 5 books in the series I still crave more.  Hugh Howey has created a compelling drama within a unique environment.  It reminded me a little of the castle in the Gormenghast Trilogy by Mervyn Peake.  An enclosed world within a world where the curious yearn for freedom.  The author spins his yarn (pardon the pun) with great detail and skilled dialogue.  The characters are well developed and fully fleshed.  This story hits a raw nerve that must be almost universally felt judging by the accolades from those of us who have spent some time running up and down the great stairway of the silo.  I feel lucky to have stumbled upon this gem and this emerging author.  I have read the Molly Fyde series and Half Way Home and they are just as good.  Hugh Howey goes on my short list of authors whose books are eagerly anticipated and avidly read.

Loved, loved, loved this book.  I really enjoyed the whole scorched earth / city of ember (but way better) vibe.  Now I just need to get my friends to read it so we can geek out on our theories that set this world in motion.

In the omnibus WOOL series Hugh Howey creates a science fiction novel that is more grounded in reality and humanity than most.  Like most of the best science fiction authors, the science fiction aspects of the story quickly take a backseat to the human condition and serve to enable us to learn about ourselves as part of the human race.  The last book I read that achieved similar results was the Sparrow.  Howey's series does this brilliantly while at the same time providing an exciting story with many unpredictable occurrences.  Second to the emphasis on human interaction for me, is the overall tone and feel of the book.  I felt a constant aura of weight and oppression throughout the story and the slight claustrophobic feeling of being trapped underground in the SILO was very effectively conveyed.  At the same time the driving force behind the plot is a balance between a building tension and impending tragedy racing a bubbling sense of hope and redemption.  The contrast between both doom and hope excellently creates that elusive feel most readers strive to capture in a story, namely the feeling that they must keep reading to find out what happens next.  Well done Mr Howey.
I can't say that I like this book. It is morose, defeated, grey and down-right depressing. It is well-written, but the world that is created is so awful that I couldn't really place myself there.

I actually picked up each of the 5 volumes for my Kindle separately and read them all in about a week.  I couldn't stop.  This omnibus edition is a great bargain and is a must if you have yet to start the series. Expect this would make a great movie.  Don't let the low price fool you.  This guy can write!

I wanted to like this book.  The reviews were outstanding.  But the truth is, when I finished this series, I felt like I had wasted days of my life.  While I feel like it COULD have been a very intriguing story, and in many ways, it was, I still feel like it was lacking in so many areas.  Perhaps the details were too tedious for my liking.  It just seems like there were so many words for such little action.  Regardless, I was greatly disappointed.

I've never submitted a review on Amazon before, but I so thoroughly enjoyed these stories that I had to post something.  I found it very difficult to put this book down and haven't been so enthralled in quite some time.  Although the novellas can stand alone, they dovetail nicely to give a 360 degree view of life in the silo.  The characters and their actions and motivations are believable, with no terribly jarring and unrealistic moments where I had to forcibly choose to maintain my suspension of disbelief to go along with the story.  I also enjoyed Howey's writing style - the dialog was natural and he provided a good amount of detail and suspense without being overly verbose.  I bought this book on a whim because of the great price, good reviews, and desire for some light vacation reading.  I was astounded by how much I enjoyed these stories and will definitely start reading Howey's other books.

I approached this trilogy (Wool, Shift, and Dust) with great anticipation, but I became increasingly disillusioned as the series progressed and, at the end, find myself moderately disappointed.  The basic premise is interesting, as is the way the backstory is gradually revealed as the main plotlines advance.  However, most of the major players, in addition to being somewhat unlikeable, are also rather superficially characterized.  Half of the 2nd volume follows an teenager as he grows up isolated from contact with others, and in addition to just not being that interesting, it reveals the main weakness of these books: the seeming lack of an editor.  The content of these three books would have made a very good single novel, and where the third leaves off would have made a good starting point for continuation of the story.  In short, these three novels are one good one stretched too thin.

This book/series was the most interesting thing I have read in a long while! I was bored at work and looking for free things to read.  I downloaded the first book for free and immediately got hooked. I bought all 5 of these books in this Omnibus Edition.  I read the whole series in a day in a half.  I am definitely recommmending it to my friends and family.

This book took hold of me and wouldn't let go. I finished the whole 5 part series in under a week. The characters are all very real and fascinating while the writing is 1st class. I'm immediately going to purchase the rest of his works. Thank you and keep writing!

If you've ever played Fallout and wondered more about life in the vault than the wasteland, this is the book for you. Howey creates a incredibly detailed world with characters you care about, and he's brave enough to keep killing them off no matter how much you love them.

As a lifelong fan of good science fiction, the Wool series blindsided me from out of left field, and I've been seeing stars ever since.  This is incredibly good.  A masterfully written, utterly approachable, all-too-real scenario of a wildly far-fetched dystopic vision of not-too-distant future Earth.  Superb character development.. an elegant, well-balanced storyline.  The Wool series doesn't attempt to awe the reader with an overdose of bombastic grandeur.. rather, the reader is simply swept away by a really damn good story, plain and simple.  So very believable.  So very unbelievable.  Clear the calendar for a few days.. once you get started on Wool, you'll not be interested in much else until you've reached the final page.  Thank you, Hugh Howley, for reminding me why I love this genre so much.  Keep writing this stuff.. and don't ever stop.

First review I ever write for Amazon. I bought these 5 books because they were cheap, with 5 stars, and had thousands of favorable reviews. After reading all those books in a week, I can tell you Mr. Hugh Howey: you are a great writer! I'm from Brazil, English is not my main language, but you write in a way that is very easy to read, understand, and feel what is going on with the chars. The story is fascinating, fast paced, fluid. Many times I knew what would happen, but it was worth reading the author's way to tell it. To anyone in doubt on buying all the collection, my suggestion is to grab it right now and give it a shot. Before these books, I always read only "blockbusters", books written by famous authors, Nebula and Hugo winners. Thanks to Wool - Omnibus Edition, I discovered a new world. A very interesting new world.

I had fallen down the Amazon Rabbit Hole, looking for something to read while waiting (impatiently) for Justin Cronin's "The Twelve" to be released and my mouse settled on Wool - Omnibus Edition. It was the last line of the description that sucked me in..."they are given exactly what they ask for..." How can you click away from that?!?!?! I don't get a lot of time to read during my days, but I've been reading my equivalent of "can't put it down". ("The Twelve" has been out for a few weeks already - I haven't touched it...I'll get there, but I have to find out what happens!!! I'm just finishing up Book 5. This is smart reading, and you can't help but become part of the Silo. It's a must-read!!!

WHY did I waste hours of my life reading this poorly written, amateurish swill when I could have been hitting myself in the head with a rubber mallet? It would have been less painful. There is NO WAY those 5 star ratings are legitimate. Barely two dimensional characters, page after page of cliché and inane descriptions of pointless acts. You've got a deputy that talks like he's from a small town in Texas. You've got this secret, geriatric love affair in the beginning so badly contrived and written, you want the water in BOTH canteens to be poisoned. At some point, EVERYBODY'S got tears running down their cheeks, muttering curses that don't fit the situation. Notice not a single person in this poopfest nods their head; everybody 'bobs' their head. How many times can you describe something as 'tangy'?! No character development, page after page of the author over describing trivial things and describing technical things he obviously did no research on and knows nothing about....ugh. My head hurts. I will repeat one last thing before I forget this horrendous book forever; There is NO WAY those 5 star ratings are legitimate.
I bought this book because it was the highest rated sci-fi book on Amazon. It was really nothing special. I kept expecting it to get better, by  it just dragged on.

I was reading on my lunch break, going to bed early (to read), and otherwise structuring my life around finishing this story.  After some pretty heavy political philosophy, I was looking a nice light sci-fi read, and I got more than I bargained for.  The mystery, characters, and world created by Howey were utterly believable and wonderfully detailed, and the structure of the plot kept bringing to mind complementary comparisons to Asimov's Foundation Trilogy.  Can't wait to read the rest - prequels, sequels... I need to pace myself, if only to make sure I don't lose touch with my real life up here on the surface.

I was so hesitant to read this because I am not much of a Sci-Fi guy, but I am glad I did.  The characters were fully developed and I felt that I was in the silo with them.  It's crazy I have seen Wool on Amazon for a while and always ignored it unknowingly that it is now in my top 5 books.  I would recommend this book to anyone that knows how to read.  Yes that broad of an audience.  I always wish Amazon would allow 1/2 stars, but now I wish they would allow you to give more than 5 because giving Wool only 5 stars does not give justice.  Awesome book.  Do not miss the opportunity to read this book!

I'll admit I was a bit skeptical at all of the positive reviews but for the price (Omnibus Edition) I figured I'd give it a try. Glad I bought the 5 story edition because had I stopped after the first book I would have been disappointed. The story just kept getting better and by the time I was on number 3 I could not put it down. If you read this on a Kindle, as I did, make sure you read past the Q and A section at the end of book 5 to find a lone chapter that I thought important to the story. I've suggested this book to friends and coworkers and hope to read more on these characters in the future.

I'm a college kid and this last semester before graduation is winding down. So, naturally, I am real busy. I barely have time to wrap up school assignments or see all of my friends, let alone free time to myself. Yet, despite this constant nagging in the back of my mind as if I am forgetting to do something, I find myself spending precious hours burning through Wool's Pages. This book is never boring, but unfortunately for me that means I will never put it down. Weird to admit it, but this is the first book I've read through fully in years. Glad I did though, because I forgot how much I enjoyed it.

I have always been a reader. One of my co-workers told me about this book and I was intrigued with the description.  I have a Amazon Kindle Fire and love it.  The great thing about these books is that it kept me guessing and it wasn't like some science fiction books that you read that are very "oh I knew that was coming".  Also the relationship between the characters was very fluid and genuine.  The story really makes you think about things you take for granted because of what is taught to you.  Very interesting metaphor.  I can't wait to read more of his books.

WOOL is an outstanding novel.  Not just a sci-fi novel or a dystopian-future novel or an underground silo subgenre of a novel, but as a novel.  It is compellingly written with believable characters who are developed naturally in an interesting milieu that is revealed slowly and realistically.  The plot did not let me go, and I read it straight through with minimal pauses.  Now I look forward to reading more of this exciting young novelist, who was discovered over the Net less than two years ago and now stands at the top of his profession. Don't miss WOOL!

Great collection of the Wool books. Wool 1 & 3 are the best stories, while 2 & 4 feel more like bridge works between the odd books.  Wool 1-3 are each told from the point of view of one person and have one theme - I especially enjoy the journey of 1 and 3 because you know the conclusion at the start of the story and then learn how that came to be.  Wool 4 and 5 are told from many different points of view and aren't quite as focused.  All of the stories are an enjoyable read and leave a painting of a world that you'd like to see more stories from.

I was so impressed with this book!  Mr. Howey has crafted a well-thought out, well developed, gripping read.  The characters have great depth -- even the villains are multi-dimensional.  So often I read a book, especially in the science-fiction genre, and find one sticking point where I think, "but why didn't they ever figure out..." or some plot point that never quite fits or makes sense.  I never ran across that with this book.  Howey is the best writer I've run across in a long time and I can't wait to read more.

So I haven't picked up a book since Orson Scott Card's Ender's Game nearly 15 years ago - not sure how that's happened, but it did.  After buying a Kindle Fire last month, I decided to try reading a short book on it and grabbed the first of the Wool books.  Well, I was finished with that before I knew it and needed more.  So I started on the Omnibus edition, and just finished it last night...still wish there was more, so I'm looking forward to the new First Shift books that sound like they're coming soon from Mr. Howey.  In the meantime, I think I'll have to try out the Molly Fyde series as it seems to get reviews as glowing as the Wool series.  Can't wait to see for myself.  Definitely give this a read...you won't regret it.

I rate 3 stars when the book fills downtime and the story or characters move along.  4 when I will make time to read because it has my interest.  5 when I find well developed plotlines, characters that could be as real as you or me, and the ability to string together memorable lines time and again.  I will be adding Hugh to my authors to read going forward.  A thanks also to Mike Gallagher for noting the good read in his books and tips blog.  I will pay regular prices for my next Hugh book.

I enjoyed all of these stories, although I felt the last one dragged a little bit. Overall this author has a very elegant, succinct style of writing, which I really appreciate. I found parts of it to be very amusing, especially when the protagonist was revealed. I found the storyline to be very unique and I hope to read more stories by this author. I highly recommend these stories and I agree with the previous reviewer that said they are destined to be a sci-fi classic.

Computers that run for centuries without a spare parts store, but no elevator or even rope and pulley to hoist things and people up and down. No explanation of how one person (and several children) survived for 32 years in a mostly destroyed silo; no explanation of the other 48 silos. The protagonist burned over 100% of her body yet up and hugging people in mere days, walking down unassisted to the bottom of the silo despite the absence of a burn clinic or modern medical care of any kind. A phone system more like Pepsi cans with string attached linking all the silos through some underground wiring system that seems impervious to the years. The war over and the bad guys vanquished but again, no explanation of how that occurred. Endless detail about trivial things like equipment, knives, water canisters - but shallow, unbelievable story and characterizations. An ending that just drops dead as if the pen ran out of ink.

I bought this because it was cheap and I had some time to kill. The first part was written as a stand alone and it was good. You can kind of feel the hiccup as part two starts and it's a little slow but press on. By the halfway mark of part 3 I was fully engaged and knowing this is a bit trite I simply couldn't stop reading. My plan is to read all of his books now. This was a real find and I can't recommend it highly enough.

I suspect this author can write a story about paint drying and the reader will actually care.  Do not expect light reading.  You will become engrossed almost immediately.  I prefer reading about a hero (easier to indentify with) but the heroine of this story is superb.  I'm only upset that I didn't find him sooner.  Calling this book science fiction is like calling a corvette a car. This is a book you will not regret buying.

Hugh Howey makes other scifi authors look silly. The genre is riddled with high concepts and formulaic junk food. The plotting reflects the authors have merely gone through the motions to meet a page requirement while the characters are shallow and boring shells who serve only to advance the predictable plot. Any reader of this instant scifi classic can tell you: nothing is shallow in the world of Wool.

I loved this book and the subsequent books 2, 3, 4, 5.  I just got more and more interested with each book I read.  The characters are so interesting and multidimensional.  And frankly the situation is very believable as was the fully fortified bomb shelter.  But this environment is so extensive and well thought out that I was fascinated.  Couldn't put them down and want Wool6 to be written.

It is unnecessary for me to add to the praise of this book; however I feel compelled to add my voice to the chorus cheering Wool.  I found it refreshing, ambitious, subtle and sharp.  I am so encouraged that a talent like Mr. Howey and a book like Wool found success from the masses and I am grateful to read further fruits of Mr. Howey's imagination.  Read Wool.  You will be glad you did.

This was a great read! I could not put it down after I started it. Not many books or games ever set my imagination wild but this book sure has. I could smell that dank of silo 17. The only thing that could make storys 1-5 better is to release story 6/9. I would love to re-live it as a movie or an acted book on tape. I will buy the next Wool book in hard copy and kindle.

Absolutely amazing. I kid you not when I say that this stacks up with some of the best books i've ever read (right up there with Foundation, Dark Tower)...i seriously couldn't put it down. I kept reading so long at a coffee shop that I got a ticket for parking there over 2 hours. If you don't buy this book then sorry for ya, you are missing out on one hell of a read:)

Epic.  Beautiful.  Intriguing.  This is the best new Sci-Fi I've read in a long time.  The character and story development are blended seamlessly and well-balanced.  I felt as if I were actually there, struggling alongside people I truly cared about.  I'm reluctant to return this 'borrowed' book as I do see it as a story that I'd like to revisit in the future.  If there are new volumes added to this tale, I would gladly pay money to read them.  Do NOT deprive yourself, read this.  You won't regret it!

This tries to be a science fiction tale, but the science part is woefully weak.  For example, at one point the heroine descends several hundred feet under water using what amounts to an old fashioned hard hat diving suit.  It's supplied by a small gasoline powered air compressor one person can carry.  When the compressor fails she just returns to the surface.  Even two hundred feet depth requires exotic breathing gasses and heavy duty equipment.  Real divers in this kind of equipment are crushed by water pressure when the air fails.  When they return to the surface too rapidly they die from decompression sickness, aka "the bends."  Some Harry Potter magic might have been better.
This book was OK...really good concept and development of the plot but just never grabbed me. I kept reading because I wanted to see how it ended, not because I was invested in the story.
Hugh Howey nailed it. What a great story for cheap! One of the best Sci Fi purchases I've made on my Kindle.

Great science fiction story told with a unique writing style. The plot moves at the right pace, keeping the readers attention, but also bringing the characters to life.  I thoroughly enjoyed this book and will be reading the second book Shift.  I also have enjoyed the audio version of Wool.

I stumbled upon this series by accident and I'm hooked! I'm about to go buy the next book and then anxiously await the third!  A series that is so realistic and plausible in this age of supernatural sagas is so refreshing!

Inside you will meet some great characters, from the tragic to the heroic they are all well written.  The story reminds and warns of what were are capable of as humans.  Howey's writing make you feel their pain, their love and their sacrifice.  One must not forget the role the setting plays. At times the silo feels so expansive, journey's often take days! At others, so claustrophobic you'll be holding your breath and not know it. A definite must read.
There is a reason this book has so much buzz, and its not because of how it was published. It is a must read.

This book was perfection. It seems incredible that this came from a novice writer who self-published - it's so clean and tight. The characters are deep, the story unique, the right amount of action and inaction. This is a book that stuck with me; I think about it often. I can't wait to read the follow=ups!

The Silo Saga is top-notch science-fiction, and is, for the most part, beautifully written. I can't believe this book was really self published. A thought-provoking story, with unexpected but believable plot twists that move the story along nicely. After reading The Road I had lost interest in post-apocalyptic stories, but this book has renewed my interest in that genre. I look forward to reading Mr. Howey's other books.
If you love books about the end of the world, then read this book!! The prospect of a 9th and final book makes me shiver in anticipation. I devoured the first 8. Read and enjoy!

I love well written, smart, surprising science fiction, and this fits the bill thoroughly. The world of the silo and the people in it are rendered in all the complex, wonderful imperfection you'd expect from a master fiction writer. This book had me on the edge of my mental seat over and over. I found myself, at times, putting the book down only to delay reading the last page. I delighted in guessing ahead but was just as happy when the author sent me around a blind curve. Kudos to Hugh Howey for crafting this story, I will recommending it to all my friends as a very smart read, a mystery set in a post-apocalyptic dystopia... what could be tastier than that?

Great read for anybody! The characters, setting, and plot are all fantastic and have their own little complexities that make you keep reading! Howey has something new and unexpected for you in every chapter. Defiantly in my top 5 favorite books.
This book is highly entertaining.  My adrenaline glads got a good workout.  Thank you Howey for an absolutely captivating read but curse you for destroying my sleep schedule!

Wool was written so well and had me hooked from the beginning.  Every time I put the book down I couldn't help but think of the characters and what was going to happen next.  That's another thing, I didn't know what was coming next!  It's not good to figure out an entire book from the start and I enjoyed this story unfolding into all directions.  WOW!  I really loved 'Wool' and highly recommend it to be read.

I bought these books separately as they came out and loved them.  When the collection came out, I bought that and retread the series.  I gained more insights the second time and appreciated the authors talents more.  If you like SyFy, it is a must read

I'm with the masses on this one. There are a few things wrong with this book, but with almost 4,000 reviews it is still hovering at the 5 star mark. There are some complex themes, but they are not explored on a deep level. The ending was really not that awesome. The science was flawed and some of the rationale as to why things were the way they were was just not that compelling. For example if someone refuses to clean, why would the manual automatically assume a rebellion is underway? Similar explanations were somewhat superficial throughout the book.  Wool is sometimes referred to as Young Adult science fiction. The writing is definitely at a level that makes it accessible to a wide variety of readers. The bottom line here is that I could not put this book down. The characters were really well drawn and compelling, the universe of the silos and their strange ways was so incredibly interesting. I set aside a couple of Saturdays to get through it and I refused to touch it during the week because I knew I wouldn't be able to stop. About 10 pages into the story, I was hooked.  This was some of the most riveting writing I've read in a long long time. I absolutely loved it!! It was a truly entertaining read.

Five stars for an amazingly fun read.  The characters truly come to life and each chapter ends with the reader (me) begging for more!  I can't wait to begin the Shift saga to continue this exciting ride.  PS I read a review that there is no Wool in the story, untrue...Jahns knitted and they clean the sensors with wool.  Just had to set the record straight ;)
I truly enjoyed this series in the omnibus edition! The story is engaging and moves quickly. I would recommend this book to family and friends. I have found a new author to follow as well!
For Christmas 2011 I was given a copy of Wool and received the omnibus for Christmas 2012. Best gifts ever.

My favorite type of book in the world is the "I'll just read one more chapter, oh crud it's 3am" read.  Wool is EXACTLY that kind of book.  You'll find yourself gripped in the story late at night.  It's perfectly paced and set up to suck you in to the world.  The entire world of Wool is well thought out and fully congruent - it all makes perfect sense and doesn't feel constructed, it just feels real.  This is a MUST READ for any sci fi, or general fiction fan.
Amazon suggested this, and after reading the sample, I was hooked!  You can barely tell that this started as a short story, and got expanded.  Definitely a fun read!

Without giving anything away, it is fair to say that this Wool is unique. It is a fresh and new take on post-apocalyptic science fiction. I especially enjoyed how the story progresses with different characters, each human, engaging and believable.

The wool series drew me in within a few pages.  I downloaded this to my Kindle and couldn't put it down.  Hugh creates a world in these silos that makes you want to go there to visit.  You want to meet these people and see how society has survived living underground.  As the series moves on you find out secrets that even the residents of the silos down't know and it draws you in even more.  I found myself caring about the characters and wanting to know how things turned out.  Love Hugh Howey as an author too, I recommend all of his books!
This is a great find and a great read.......thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you
Wow. This book was awesome. The pacing was perfect. I just could not put it down.Howey is amazing. He has invented a world that fully captivated my imagination.

A brand new constraint on human existence lets us look at the human condition through Hugh Howey's unique lens. Involving, compelling and I now need to know what happened before and what will happen next. The first I have already started on in the prequel series and then I will have to wait and hope for a sequel.

Found this as a recommended read when searching  in other favorite authors, e.g. Phiip K Dick. Dystopian tale of a future that seems quite possible on several levels. A good and enjoyable read. You'll like this.
Thoroughly enjoyed this book. Would recommend it to anyone who enjoys this type of futuristic novels. Highly recommended and those who don't usually read this type may really enjoy it also.

Whether you like SF or not, you must read this book.  The author's writing transcends SF genre and is written so simple and eloquently, it is pure poetry on paper.  Plot, believability, character development, mystery and suspense.  This book has it all.  There is also the prequel written after wool, but I didn't like that nearly as much as Wool Omnibus.

If it weren't for the article in the WSJ last week I would never of come across these amazing stories. A warning to those who have yet to start, the first one is free for a reason. Once you start you will not be able to stop. Enjoy it while it lasts.

This is a very good bit of sci fi that sets up an interesting situation, of all these people living in this silo in the ground with some rather brutal rules.  A lot happens and you learn more but not all in this book about what the silo might be.  Read First shift to find out who built the silo and why?  That is good too, though is slower. These keep me really engrossed.  Great concept and fun read.

Each additional volume of this series makes you feel more and more as though you are physically living in the Silo. I couldn't stop reading. Read all editions in one sitting then when onto First Shift. Now I am getting ready to read Second Shift then Third Shift. Hugh Howey knows how to grab you and make you feel like part of the story and really makes you hate the world we are living in. I can see this happening, it probley already is. Wool is a MUST read!!
A phenomenal story. I never had any idea what was going to happen next, the authors kept surprising me. Absolutely amazing. Highly recommended
good charatcer development, vivid imagery.  I have read the sequel and am now waiting for the next instalment. Hopefully next month.

I purchased this "omnibus" mostly because it was inexpensive and in a genre I enjoy. It didn't take me long to realize I'd made a really good decision. It is rare that I talk about my ever-streaming series of novels to my husband but this one made me want to talk. I had to tell him all about the world the characters found themselves in, how pleased I was by the premise, the strong female lead, the challenges. I got really into it. I will be adding this author to my watch list.

The book is highly recommended ! The language is extremely simple and the point of view is very consistent . The book moves at a relaxing pace and is extremely absorbing without being dull or loose. Plot points are tight and the other characters are complex and completely fleshed out thus adding to the well crafted feel of the book.

I loved this book. i was captivated. i literally stayed up all night to finish it. And then called my friend in another state at like four in the am to talk about some of the theories and perspectives discussed in the books. we talked for hours! We joked about it not having any cool robots! :) But robots aside... it was friggin brilliant! We are really all connected!
Couldn't put this book down.  Very original story. Can't wait to find out what is going on in the rest of this new world.

When I first read Wool, it had been ages since I had truly devoured a book, that a book captured my attention so thoroughly that I couldn't put it down until I had completed it.  Wool was the first book I read using my new smartphone and its Kindle app, and while my eyes may not have been thanking me at the end, I just kept wanting more of the series. Hugh Howey has this magical ability to create such fascinating stories and mysteries that pulls the reader along (and if you know anything about the guy, he's probably one of the most friendly authors out there and really dedicated to his fan base), and I would highly recommend to every lover of science fiction to read his books...or anyone who loves to read! Be prepared to purchase his other Silo books after finishing the Omnibus though, you won't want to stop!

I was so impressed by his book.  I have just started reading more scifi books and after this series I will continue to do so.  I just got done reading the enders game series and I was disappointed with all but the first book.  I was afraid this would be the same way but it was so cheap I figured why not.  Well I am glad I did.  The first book was short but still awesome and got me hooked.  I thought all the others where just as good.  I just bought part six of this series and and cant wait to read more.

So, why did I get these books? Because I'm cheap and I'll read almost anything. So imagine my surprise when I wasn't just reading, but actually enjoying! This doesn't happen all the time as you e-book readers out there know. A cheap book can be nothing but cheap, but wool is a good read with a excellent handle on what true post apocalypse life would mostly be like. A decade after a nuke war and above ground life would not be livable, nor at a century for that matter! Hugh Howey shows us a world where the life of a country is bottled up, and stored away, and all that happens inside the bottle. Good read at a good price. Thank you Hugh Howdy, now where's my next installment of Wool already!!!

Great book. Surprised it isnt a top 10 the NY best seller .  What a great opportunity for writers and, now that i think about it,  never mind the NY best seller list. The world has changed for good writers thanks to Amazon. Can't wait for the next episode.

The Silo Saga is just terrific. It's so inspiring that this series started out as singles published by the author. Just goes to show you that cream rises to the top. I highly recommend this as a terrific read for all ages YA on up.

I loved this book. That's actually saying a lot as I usually avoid sci-fi. I also have a tendency to skim ahead while reading suspenseful parts in stories, with Wool Omnibus 1-5, I didn't want to miss a word. This book made me Hugh Howley fan, I can't wait to read more of his work.
This book is awesome. I how they all ways throw out main characters it makes things so dramatic. Sorry about the spelling I'm only 8 NO joke I'm using my dad's kindle fire to read this

Reminds me of an ant hill with blind devotion to the collective. Nobody ask the question or gives an opinion without the possibility of dire consequences. A very well constructive narrative and characters who finally have the courage to be individualistic and have some personal incentive to question the decision makers. This was a heads up when you relinquish the day to day way of life to bureaucracy. The"Wool" no pun intended gets pulled over your eyes and fear is the equation for governing. Very enlightening and disturbing read, a story for everyone.
One of the best post apocalyptic stories I have read. I would recommend this book to everyone. Please write more of these.

Instantly!  Instantly I was immersed in Hugh Howey's silo world of the future.  How an author can be so concise and descriptive at the same time is refreshing.
