The book is too prosey---I would have liked it better if there was less narrative prose.  The main character has no character arc--kinda dull in that respect.  The two characters who do have character arcs, Peter and Solo, are hardly even tertiary characters.  The plot is interesting, but not interesting enough to make up for the lack of interesting characters.  The first section of the book is about a character who isn't centrally important to the main narrative... I kept waiting for Holston's thread to mean something, but it doesn't.  I thought it was funny that Solo's real name is Jimmy; reminds me of another character named Jimmy who goes by another name, "Snowman," (from Oryx and Crake).  I actually thought that that this book was going to at least be better than Oryx and Crake, but was quite underwhelmed with how the end was tied together.  One day I might get around to reading the squeal to that other Jimmy book (Oryx and Crake); however, I'll save my speculative fiction reading to more speculative speculative fiction books, hopefully ones with bigger words and ideas than wool had.  Maybe if you like Dan Brown books you will like Hugh Howey.  It's not my cup of tea, but obviously it sells books and it is other people's cups of tea :)

This book was recommended by a friend. It is a good read, but nothing I haven't read before. I enjoyed the concept and the scifi feel, but I must say the end was predictable. I would recommend this book, but not if you are looking to read a book with crazy twists and turns.
I would describe the book(s) as a sort of underground version of the show Lost.  A very enjoyable read, captivating and addictive.  I'm definitely looking forward to the next books.
I stayed up until 4am reading this and it was so very worth it.  Great plot, great characters, extremely believable premise.
This is one of the best I've ever read certainly the first I've ever been moved to give a thumbs up. Was told of this by a co-worker and now I'm happily hooked!

A really great SciFi read.  The end of the world has come and gone, but there are survivors hundreds of years later who are totally ignorant of the fact.  A secret found followed by a tragedy is about to set a world ablaze for at least one small contained universe.  These were originally issued as a series of short interlinked novels and I'm glad I waited till the omnibus edition was available to read the foll story.  It has genuinely nail biting moments and a satisfying end. Despite that I would still love to read more about these characters and their world.  If you are looking for a good scifi read this author is worth taking a chance on.

...as I would not have had enough at the end of one. Actually come to think of it I would like another five please! This is such a well written story in a genre that can often be so hit and miss. It is fantastic when you take a punt on something self published and it is actually really, really worthwhile. The story line moves at a cracking pace, I genuinely couldn't guess what came next and was often surprised. The characters were likable and the new take on an old theme was truly original. Buy this book, I highly doubt you'll regret it.

I normally don't write reviews for things but this series was so awesome that I had to make the exception. I did a sample of the series to see if I would like it which gave me the 1st book and part of the second and as soon as I was finished with the sample I was buying the series. I finished it in about 5 days (reading at night) because I could not put my kindle down. It moved at a fast pace with something at every turn. There were many a times I would end the chapter and a "oh my gosh" would come out of my mouth. I can't wait to read more of what Hugh Howey has to offer and I hope we get to see more of the silo's stories soon.

The author manages to make the admittedly well-worn genre of post-apocalyptic sci-fi seem fresh again.  The characters are engaging, the story moves along at a good clip, and the world is well-considered and fleshed out.
Good premise and story. Always fun to find another twist to a post apocalyptic world. Well written, waiting for continuation.

Like the previous reviewer, I have read hundreds of sci-fi books.  Some have good ideas, some have good writing.  It's pretty rare to find both.  Wool is great writing about a fascinating idea.  The author, in his modesty, has vastly underpriced his work -- it would be a bargain at three times the price.  Read it NOW!
I started reading this book and was hooked in the first 2 pages. I couldnt put it down untill I was done.

I'm not going to write a lengthy review. For those of you who are reading the review to see opinions about the book and if you should read it or not. This one is for you. First, I will have to say, I had never heard of this author until about a week ago. I am now reading all his books and craving for more. Wool 1-5 is a wonderful, amazing story line that makes me wish there was more. The story is great, the suspense is great. It is an easy read and keeps you captivated. I finished all 5 of the wool series in about 20 hours. I would have finished sooner if life did not get in the way. I could not put it down. If you need a new good author and book to read. This one is for you!

I am not usually a fan of post-apocalytic sci-fi, but I loved this series. At first I was not sure how I would like it, but for the omnibus price, I figured it was worth a shot. By the end of the first story, I was hooked. Characters are well written, the science and technology is pretty solid, the sociology of the silo is well thought out. Everything seemed plausable- I never got that jarring sensation that something wasn't "realistic" enough- no suspension of disbelief needed!  I would definitely recommend this. Would love to read more.

It's so hard to review this without giving anything away! There's the picture, the bigger picture, and then the biggest picture of all... I'm so glad I read this, and I'm anxiously awaiting the author's next entry in the Wool saga.
I literally couldn't put this down or sleep until I finished it. The story was griping and I recommend it for anyone looking for a great read.

The end of every book was completely unpredictable, including the final ending of the series (and in a good way). Its great to read something that feel completely different from anything I've read before so far. Great series! Definitely will read the other ones.

I bought the audiobook because of all the 5 star ratings. I listen to books on my drive to and from work. The beginning of this book had me excited at the premise. This could be awesome. However, the author is an independent publisher so he appears to have stretched this story out into multiple volumes to make sure you buy the later volumes because you are so invested in the story. Just one problem with that model in his case. He didn't have enough story to fill the hundreds of pages he needed to meet his goal. The drag is just incredible. Audio Books are expensive so I listen to the end regardless. This book was torture to me. I actually dreaded driving home from work because I knew I would be shouting at the reader to "Just hurry up for god's sake. #$@%^. Every morning. I gave it two stars because the premise is interesting and some how he keeps you wanting to know the ending even while you are hating the pages and pages of droning on about nothing. There is one point where one of the characters is trying to swim with no air from the bottom to several levels higher where she can breath again. I swear it took ten pages or more. Every little stinking thing was described ad nauseam. I almost quit right there but I wanted to know what was outside the silo. That's how he gets you and keeps you captive in a way that is worse than what the inhabitants have to go through. Another thing that ticks me off? Is there are so many variations of books in this series that you can't tell what the order is. Bad marketing or intentionally trying to get you to buy multiples of parts of the series by mistake you be the judge.

...I'm really not going to bother saying much, except that I completely enjoyed this book(s), wish I could lend Kindle version to friends, and look forward to a sequel. I just bought this author's first book Molly Fyde and can't wait to get started on it!

And I'm always a sucker for this kind of stuff, but; it's a bit too close to the plot line of A Discovery of Witches and without that book's interesting factual/historical detail. An okay read for a bit of fun, not sure I'll bother with the next one.

Several hundred years after an apocalypse. Several silo's were built to house very many people. Each silo is isolated without knowing about one another. The novel flows smoothly, strong characters, and wonderful strong plot, which you will love. Yes, I could easily imagine that this is exactly the way it would be under these circumstances. I was disappointed in the ending, as it left me hanging...sort of, well it did have a good ending, but I thought the author could have easily made the book much longer. In fact, he needed to. There were a lot of things he could have added to make it longer. Instead of 509 pages, it could have been 700 pages that he could have had a better closure. I do think there will be a second book, maybe a trilogy. As I read  toward final chapter I kept asking myself, "How could all this wrap up in the final chapter?" It didn't completely. At the end of the book the author answers several questions. One ask, "Is this really the end?" He said, "There's always another story to tell. Just maybe not the one readers expect". There you go, that question was no surprise for me, but the author's answer SHOULD have been, "Read book #2". So, this question was exactly what I had been asking myself and still did not get the correct answer. This book took three years to write- how long till a second if there is one? It was still a great book overall. Since writing this review, I've learned there are 5 books in this series, but no where in the first book does it state that which was a huge mistake on the author's part.. Good !!

I loved the first chapter, which started out as a short story. Filled with fear and hope and leaving me wanting more. But the additional chapters were filled with so much death for so very very long, page after page after page... Not gory details but just constant loss, over and over again. I had to finish the book, even though it was really depressing me, just to bring me out of a very deep funk. I almost feared the ending would be just more tragedy and I am relieved and thankful that at least it came to a more hopeful conclusion. I wish Mr. Howey had inserted a few more hopeful moments in the middle of the book. Just a tendril here and there. Or changed some of the loss to challenges instead of just constant never ending tragedy... Granted I will be the first to admit I couldn't write anything this good ever... The story premise is awesome, the writing and characters fabulous, but with page after page - after page - of death and fear, I found myself not enjoying the read for quite bit of the book.  So I finished the book feeling very conflicted... Thrilled with the outcomes for characters I had grown to know, but I was left so emotionally exhausted and abused in the process of getting there... I have read books of "constant tragedy" before, such as Tolkien and Paolini, but something about Mr. Howey's writing, while it left me compelled to keep reading, it also so depressed and upset me while reading the bulk of it. I think I will still have to try another of his books and see if they feel as painful and depressing to read; I truly hope not!

What a pleasant surprise! It's not quite up to the best of Gene Wolfe, but this is high quality writing, high quality world building, and excellent character building. Looking forward to more from this author. Can't recommend highly enough.

The writer skillfully painted a picture in my mind of every character, place, plot, and grabbed me from the beginning.  I couldn't put it down and never wanted it to end.  It was very well written and an extremely creative story.  LOVED it!

What an amazing piece of science fiction. Proof that self-published novels can be every bit as good (and probably in most cases so much better) than what the publishing houses decide is fit to print. Spend $5 and enjoy yourself.

Unfortunately, the writers style is not for me.  He is too detailed in his story telling.  The first 4th of the book was characters walking down stairs and up stairs - way too many pages dedicated to that scene.  The story did not pick up until 70% and then it ended abruptly.  I wanted to find out what happens next to the other silos - but I will not read from this author again.

The plot is derivative, the characters undeveloped stereotypes and the technology self-contradictory, but the action moves forward, albeit predictably. I am surprised at the success and the large number of glowing reviews.

My husband mentioned hearing about a book called "Wool", which was very popular as an e-book, and was science fiction. Might have been on NPR, or in the Wall St. Journal. He wasn't sure, but I had just finished "Dearie", a superb biography of Julia Child, and was without a book and desperate for an excellent consumingly good one, since I had just come off a fabulous 'read'. Praying that it would be dystopian fiction rather than just science fiction, I snuck my daughter's Kindle out of her room and downloaded the e-book. First paragraph made me stop for a prayer of thanks: I knew I was in the best of hands. I could barely work and feed the family for the next two days, captivated and distracted by this amazing, compelling, heartfelt and brilliant story, wonderfully and vividly told. I could see it: I could SEE the view projected on the walls, and the wheat-colored dirt-and-dust outdoors, the steps and the blue and yellow jumpsuits, and feel terror during the big swim and long walk. It was beyond my deepest hope for a transporting, thrilling, heartbreaking and thought-provoking transcendant read. My heartfelt thanks to Mr. Howey, and may he write on and on and on and make tons of money so that he can have whatever he needs to make more books, and also be happy. What a gift. I am now going to buy all his other works, one by one. (this says I bought the book as a paperback, but in fact I bought it as an e-book.)

At the suggestion of an author I recently reviewed, I finally got around to reading Wool by Hugh Howey and was greatly pleased with the recommendation.  It seems I benefited from being a little late to the game as the first five stories had been bundled together while I procrastinated. This story is extremely well done from start to finish. I not only enjoyed it, but life pretty much came to a halt as I read it over the Memorial Day holiday. Another good indication of the story's quality is that I immediately purchased First Shift - Legacy (Part 6 of the Silo Series) within hours of finishing because I'd run out of book and wasn't ready for the story to end. Wool was so well done. I was truly intrigued by the characters and found myself fully involved especially once Juliette's struggles began in this controlled and broken world of the silo. She was a great character - independent, intelligent, feisty, compassionate, loyal and willing to overcome any odds to survive against seemingly impossible odds. One of those characters who brings to mind the phrase indomitable will and I truly enjoyed this story from start to finish. Everything about this story was well done from social dynamics to the uncovering of the hidden truths. I can only suggest that you read it and hope that you enjoy the experience as much as I did. I'd give it more than a 5, but that's as high as the rating scale goes.

This is science fiction that works for people who don't like science fiction. This was a great story, well written, with interesting characters, plot, and continuity. It did however remind me  a lot of Logan's Run.

With almost 2000 reviews at the time of this writing, there is no need for me to be anything but brief with these comments. I like to support these "underground" (pun intended) books, however, so I feel this work and author deserve my review. First off, I think Hugh Howey has one of the most imaginative minds going right now. The overall concept of this story (which is still continuing) is fascinating, and the themes introduced take this beyond normal "science fiction". There are several primary characters featured throughout the five books of the Omnibus edition, but Howey does a great job giving them all a unique voice and story. My only criticism is that the ending to the fifth book felt very rushed. After pages of build up, the ending sort of just happened and then that was the end. There did not appear to be a climax to the story, with everything just "working out". I understand that this isn't the end of the overall series, but prior to the fifth book, each story seemed to have a natural conclusion. The fifth, however, made me feel like I had skipped over several pages, as if the author saw the finish line and dashed for it rather than continuing the pace set previously. Not a huge deal, since I still really enjoyed the book, but I wanted a little more. I look forward to the rest of the volumes, though.
I bought the Kindle edition of this book based on reviews, and I'm so so so glad I did.  Absolutely engrossing and believable.  I wasn't ready for it to end!  Can't wait to read more.  Thanks, Hugh!
Loved it! I am addicted to post apocalyptic stories/movies and this is one of the most original versions ever written. It will make a fantastic movie. Best part is I read it as a kindle free book!
I couldn't put it down. This book will be a classic sci fi read one day. Would also make a great film! Strong female protagonist is a plus. The only thig I hope is that this story is not the end.

First of all, pay NO attention to reviews comparing this to 'The Hunger Games'. The plot involves a dystopian future. There. That is where all similarity between 'Wool' and 'The Hunger Games' begins and ends. This is a post-apocalyptic novel set in a very bleak and hostile future world where most of mankind has died in what characters euphemistically refer to as 'the uprising'. I simply refuse to give away any of the more intricate plot details. You need to read it for yourself. Suffice it to say, this vision of the future is very dark and grim. However, what sets this book apart in a science fiction sub-genre that is already over crowded with sub par writing is the prose itself. Howey is simply an exceptional writer. If I had to draw a comparison, it would be to Justin Cronin, another favorite author of mine. He just captures so much feeling and emotional impact...he writes on another level. If you're looking for a slam bag shoot-em-up zombie holocaust book, look elsewhere. There are plenty of those, and some of them are even good. But if you're looking for a post apocalyptic adventure on the grand scale of 'The Passage' or 'The Stand', then look no further. You've found your book. Highly recommended. A future sci-fi classic in the making.
Wool 1 was interesting and had more substance than the other 4. It was like a bus ride that you enjoyed and saw interesting things on the first leg and then it traveled in to an area of blight.

This was my first exposure to the world of Wool and it has been a one of the best investments of my money for me.  The writing style is nothing fancy but the author's cleverness comes through in how he presents the characters and the world of the Silo.  Mr. Howey skillfully feeds the reader only enough background and technical information to entice them through each story.  Through the scant descriptions of the Silo and the way of life in it he creates another character that engages the reader's imagination in such a manner that you will thinking about the world of Wool even long after you have put down the book.  It will cause you to rethink your opinions of what makes people evil.  Is it acting in their own best interests and being selfish or performing deeds for a greater good that is that has been handed down and not validated.  These stories will get your brain thinking on so many levels about the characters in this book and how things are with authority figures in your own life.  I would highly recommend this book but be forewarned as the author has only scratched the surface of the world he has created.  Mr. Howey, I'm hooked as a "Woolite" and I would gladly read the rest of your works.

The Omnibus edition comprises 5 books of the "Silo" saga.  Book one "Wool" is probably the best short book I've ever read. I found myself re-reading line after line to make sure "did read what I just thought I read"? "Let me get this straight"? "Are you f'ing kidding me"? Wool is brilliant like a "Twilight Zone" episode because it's a story that cant possibly never be dated (always relevant).  It's got a femme fatale, a massive love story overlapped by another fairly large one, a great villian. In short it has everything. It's not so much of a page turner as it is a "WTF is going to happen in these next few moments".  In fact Hugh Howey transported my body into the world that is "Wool".  What are you willing to do to keep the status quo? What are you willing to do to NOT keep the status quo? No character introduced is safe from harm in this story. They may not be killed off, but they will certainly be tested.  Ultimately though it's a story of the hero's or heros journey.  I read somewhere that Ridley Scott bought the rights.  I see this as movie, but I somehow see it even more as a AMC series. Thanks Hugh for giving me this gift. I just now saw a book 6 available. Click! It arrives next week.

I didn't love this book. while I've decided to read the series, I'm hoping that the plot evolves. 4 stars on Amazon is really misleading. It's well written and kinda smart just not that interesting or gripping like other books in a similar genre. the term 'silo' continually puts in my mind an image of pounds of dry corn falling on people like in the movie 'Witness' with Harrison Ford. overalls and silos? is this like a post apocalyptic Amish world? that would be fine, but call it Quaker world 2400. don't create a cool cover with an interesting description and then we learn it's polluted weather versus an alien species or something cooler. kinda lame. can people see outside or is it a computer generated image? confusing. why would leaders in a new world order care about keeping survivors isolated? "what we do defines us?" what does that mean?? if these are the last members of civilization, why kill them off, shouldn't the goal be to prosper and survive? killing people off cause they have questions about a world they can see but not feel?? right, they deserve to be gassed. lame. how could a government afford all this technology if the air is toxic? hopefully, I'll learn more in books 2 and 3.

Hey Mr Howey, you said you read these so I'm writing to you. :-) Wool Omnibus was a great read start to finish and exactly what I needed. I went out of my way to not read any spoilers, opinions, and didn't even want to see the covers of the later books before I read them. Gizmodo turned me on to the title I must admit. I wanted to get lost in the story I knew nothing about, to fool myself into thinking I could guess where the story was going but then end up pleasantly surprised when I was wrong. You took great care to not let the story take predictable turns and I very much appreciated that. I was surprised over and over again. I also appreciate how you didn't feel compelled to explain every detail and every transition. Sometimes time just passes and certain things had been happening for a while. We didn't need to know they got there necessarily. You expect your readers to pay attention and be able to draw certain conclusions. Well done on the nail-biting sequences building tension and suspense. I'll be going on to the 6th book for sure and will follow later iterations. I can't wait to see what's in store for our heroine, her friends, and look forward to the MOVIE. Very nice job.
Although Howey tells a good story of a post apocalyptic world he leaves gaps in the character development of his major characters that would have made the story more satisfying to me.
Absolutely fabulous reading!  This book just takes you in and you can't stop reading.  Can't wait for it to continue or be a TV series.  Would make a great one. Great writing Hugh!

I am not a traditional sci-fi fan. Probably for the same reason I shy away from poetry and music. I believe this to be my genetic deficiency, and as such, I've long since stopped fighting it. I don't read what I emotionally can't understand. There's an essential narrative framework common to these categories, and I find no place for myself inside it. But then here I was reading Wool. Why? Good question. The answer? An intriguing publishing history. By now anyone reading this review knows the book's indie history - the shining success story - but here is what I can tell you. It's a great book. Sure, I could nit-pick about certain elements (why are there no elevators in the silos?, and the ending, well, yea, saw that coming pages before it happened, but I liked Juliette enough to stick with her), but let's cut to the much bigger chase: Mr. Hugh Howey (is that your real name, I doubt it), thanks for keeping me mightily entertained for several days and evenings. Let's hope the phenom of epigenetics kicks in here, and my offspring are more attuned to metaphorical apocalyptic melodic poetic culture than I am. In any case, I'll recommend this book to them.
Engaging and well written. The author did a spectacular job keeping me entertained--what more can be said? I finished the books in 5 days!  Keep us going with more from Silo 18
It has been a while since I read a sci-fi book. This one kept me up until late in the evening. If you are only going to read one sci-fi novel this year, this is your book.

Like so many others this is my first Amazon review and also like so many others 5 stars. This book was really amazing for several reasons. I think the foremost is that book is incredibly "organic" i don't think that there is a force scene, character, or moment in the entire series everything that happens seems a logical consequence of the setting and the characters. Secondly none of the characters are really "fiction-evil" there is tons of conflict, sometimes bloody. But i don't think there is a single character who would not say that his/her actions were not in the best interest of everyone. The author does a fantastic job of making everyone understandable. After all who really knows or cares what motivates a Sauron or Cthulu? They are just are things for the heros to oppose. Here everyone is just human and fallible. Lastly the author is a great example of the "show it" "don't say it" school. No jarring walls-of-exposition, the world of the book is revealed naturally through the characters and what they do.
It really is as good as they say. This is the first sci-fi book I've read to the end in a long time. I expect and hope they make a movie of it next.

I really liked this book series.  I probably will read more as they come out.  I do have a complaint about the detailed descriptions and the sometimes snail pace of some events, while others happen without ANY description- like the first time Juliette and Lukas communicate after her "cleaning."  The author is a talented writer, however, and he keeps the suspense going.  The story was not always predictable, which I like.  The reason I got interested in the book in the first place is partly because my daughter-in-law was reading it, but mostly because she and my son had a science magazine with an article about silo living.  Apparently, someone is selling apartments in a totally self contained underground missle silo- in the event of some catastrophy.  Intriguing- until you read these books.  The endless climbing, which was off-putting to some readers, brought to life what it would be like living in one.  Maybe not so intriguing- LOL.

This was the best book I have read this year, and I agree that it will be a Science Fiction Classic. The premise is science fiction, the story is a study in social structures, and how man struggles to define and shape society. You will be enchanted, horrified, and still find hope at the end. The characters are engaging, the setting compresses their characteristics down to the essence, and one is drawn into their world where their work defines them as members in a society that falls apart when basic truths are questioned too deeply. I am reminded of Robert Heinlein's book, "The Moon is a Harsh Mistress" but with less comfort, and charm. This book makes you question the people who are in charge of any society, including our own. Reality is slowly peeled back,and we find the monster behind the mask is actually a joe trying to justify and do his odious job well-which is more disturbing than anything else that happens in the book.
This was one of the best books I have read in a long time.  I couldn't put it down.  I will definately be looking for more work by Hugh Howey.

This is the first self-published book I have ever read, and I admit to having had my doubts.  (I'm a Harvard grad and a former English major, so I will dutifully confess to the occasional bout of literary snobbery.) Now, having blazed through the entire thing in fewer than 10 days, I can honestly say that every single publishing house editor who turned this down should be fired.  Now.  It is inconceivable to me how someone could read this and not see how good it is.  Howey is a compelling, lucid writer, and the story grabs you by the throat from the beginning.  The characters are terrific, the story immersive and propulsive, the world well thought-out.  I've heard this compared to the Hunger Games, and that feels right.  I couldn't put those books down either.  Howey deserves every cent he earns on these books.  I just hope he decides to write a sequel, because I am dying to know what happens next in that world.  Bravo!

I just finished the omnibus Wool and I couldn't have asked for a better way to spend the evening of my 45th birthday than with a quart of butter pecan ice cream and a fantastic tale on my new kindle.  I am very happy to find another great storyteller.  To anyone who is thinking of reading Wool, stop thinking and start reading!  The last time I was this excited discovering an author was finding I, robot in elementary school.  I am looking forward to reading Wool 6 and browsing any other titles Mr. Howey has and will produce.  The depth of character from page one is stunning.  I turned every page seeing a complete person with none of the akwardness so many authors stumble through in the early stages of their stories.  The crisp detail of the welds, the vividness of desolation, the poignancy of despair and the "choking gall and preserving sweet" of love all conspired to while away my hours timelessly.
I bought this entire series one at a time on my kindle and loved it so much I had to buy a hard copy to be able to share with others!
An excellent, unique world filled with well-developed characters. Every book in this series maintains pace and suspense. You'll be hungry for more. What a find!

I had been excited to read Wool for quite some time, due to the fact that it was self-published and had been getting a lot of hype. Unfortunately, I found the story very hard to get in to. The highlight for me was the opening part, which was the original short story that the rest of the book was based on. This part was great, and I tore through it very quickly. After that though, I felt as if everything went down hill. The second part in particular seemed to stretch on for a long time, with very little development. The idea of the silos is a very interesting, and I loved the themes presented in the first part, but Howey took too long to develop them. I could tell that this book was written as separate short stories, so that kind of bothered me, because at times they felt disjunctive from the other parts. All in all, I was expecting better.

A captivating read.  The story moves at a good pace and reveals many layers as you go.  As things are revealed, you realize everyone is doing what they think is best for the community.  It is difficult to discuss the intricacies in any detail without spoiling some of the components of the story, but I found the psychological aspects of their particular scenario fascinating, and it was possible to find yourself empathizing with all the characters, both good and "bad".  There is a well done blend of action, suspense, and psychological drama in Wool.  This is truly a fascinating world that the author has created.  The last 200+ pages simply fly by.  I felt the climax at the end of the book almost moved too quickly, but the events that unfolded felt true to the characters.  If you like dystopian stories, you should read this book.

Hugh Howey is a wordsmith, a master of his craft.  Creating a bleak future in a dystopian world where humanity never sees the light of day and society is based on webs of lies should not be able to be told with such poetry.  Howey has an insight into how we perceive the world that enables him to describe a world, and it's people, in such a way that it all feels real and possible.  He shapes people with his words, one after another, adding detail, quirks and fictional souls until there is an entire clan of people you can imagine living in another place and time.  Each person then has a life, and a unique perspective...all layering together for this Story, making it like a living thing you can't quite imagine ending.  Thankfully, it appears that Howey has the ability to continue the story without losing his way, or his genius.
A great sci-fi read. I love how vol 1-5 of Wool is put together to make this edition. I would recommend this book to anyone!

Reading this book as a fan of Japanese science fiction anime movies and books, especially the ones by Miyazaki Hayao, I visualized the claustrophobic setting of the book as somewhat akin to the crowded industrialized landscape in Laputa and the heroine somewhat like Nausicaa. Many of the reviews here advocate turning this book into a live action movie, but why not have it turned into an anime comic or movie, having the great director and artist Miyazaki Hayao and/or his protegees on board? While I don't see any evidence of plagiarism, I do see very similar threads of inspiration between this work and a lot of the works that Mr. Miyazaki has produced over the years. Mr. Miyazaki himself has acknowledged a lot of influence from American Sci-Fi authors, so I don't think that as an implausible connection.

This has got to be one of the ten best dystopian/post-apocalyptic novels I’ve read.  I fell down the Silo’s spiral stairs to black and white memories of great old “Twilight Zone” episodes where Howey’s concrete and steel world with its pumps and generators, nuts and bolts, wrenches and soldering irons seemed more important than the high-tech computers of IT.  But this claustrophobic, constricting setting only works because the characterization is so compelling.  The story’s heroes and heroines are real people to whom the reader gets attached, and therefore suffers the consequences.  The metaphysical symbolism that encloses this world is powerful, and given the solid reality of the setting, surprising.  It is no wonder that this book emerged from the self-publishing world to be such a success.

After blazing through the first three chapters of "Wool" in a day, it took me nearly a year to finish the book. I wanted to finish it because of all the praise and great reviews. I kept thinking, "This has to get better. All those 5-star reviewers can't be wrong, can they?" So I kept reading a few sentences or couple of pages at a time until I got bored and turned to something else. To me "Wool" reads like the author wrote a good short story then said, "Hey, wouldn't it be great if I could expand this to a book!" But he didn't have enough story remaining for a whole book, so he was reduced to filling pages with long-winded descriptions, internal monologues and introducing one-dimensional characters who didn't really advance the narrative. Juliette is a great character, but she deserves better treatment. Lukas, the other character who was supposed to make us care about his fate, was a pale, passive shadow.

This story is gripping from beginning to end.  While it's full of twists and surprises, they are never befuddling to the reader or implausible or coincidental.  They make complete sense with everything in the story, even when they force you to completely revise your understanding of the Wool world.  The story is so faithful to a thoughtfully constructed world that maintaining the suspension of disbelief is effortless and the reader is free to fall in love with the characters, which I did, completely.  I loved every second of the Wool Omnibus and was constantly exclaiming to my wife how excited I was by what was happening in the story, always careful not to actually say what was happening, knowing she would read it when I finished.  Now I can't wait to read First Shift - Legacy!

I purchased the print edition of Wool - Omnibus edition and read it cover to cover. It was very hard to put down once I started reading, but it was especially hard to put down after completing the first 40 pages (Wool 1). I hate the awful feeling I have when a good book is over, so I usually pace myself, but this was a book that I just could not stop reading, even though I wanted it to last much, much longer. I need to order the 6th book (the prequel) just to keep myself involved in this futuristic world a little longer. I will be recommending this to everyone I know. I decided to purchase it by reading all of the amazing reviews this series has received, and once I finished, I knew I needed to write something as well. You will not be disappointed if you purchase this book.

I dragged myself through the whole book, hoping beyond hope that it would redeem itself and become worthy of it's nearly 5 star ratings. After I finished it, I spent the last year trying to delete it from my consciousness. It has only served as the butt of many jokes between my wife and I during this time of remorse and cleansing.

First, I must say that any book that is hard for me to put down and leaves me wanting more has done a great job. I did love this book. I am writing this review about an hour after finishing and less than a week after starting.  Part of me sees this book not unlike many of the great shows that I grew to love. My biggest frustration with the book were the questions left unanswered. But yet many were. I think back to my favorite show LOST and how it did a great job of weaving you into the story, leaving you wanting so much answered. WOOL does this as well. Part of me would love to see a part six and beyond, to see these characters lives unfold even more, and yet... like our own lives, only so much can be told. In summary, this is a must-read for me.
Hugh Howey is a seriously good story teller, with a seriously good story to tell. Literally couldn't put it down.

I know this book has a crazy amount of reviews. I know that this book is almost universally liked. Even still, I liked this book so much I wanted to express that in a review no one will likely ever read. I'm speaking of this first book (reviewing the other 2 releases later) only. From the beginning an atmosphere is created, and characters are revealed. The story while not dramatic, it is enthralling for some reason. I think it's the silo, and the unknowns, that make you want to read. Really really enjoyed this book and highly recommend it to everyone. Seriously, it's a story and book that crosses all genres really and can appeal ... scratch that ... will appeal to all readers. I was running for the next book as soon as I finished!

I love this series!  A friend of mine told me about it and told me I should read it.  She was right.  And now I'm saying YOU should read it too!  I picked up the Omnibus edition (books 1-5 in one).  Trust me when I say that if you pick up the first book (or even just read the sample), you're going to want all 5 so you might as well get them all in one shot.  It moves along quickly and leaves you wondering what could happen next.  The characters draw you into their world and you'll find yourself quickly taking sides.  My legs hurt just reading about hiking up and down the silo stairs!  (Ironically, I did most of my reading on an elliptical with this series)  I'll be downloading the "Shift" trilogy next which follows this one.

This series is brilliant. You picked up Wool 1 for free and are pondering buying the 1-5 and 6-8 collections. Do it. Period. This series is like an adult version of the schoolkid classic The Giver only, well, underground. It offers us all a mirror, a warning,  and a hope for ourselves. It is gripping. Editing is flawless. Shifts in location and time are handled not only well but in a nicely interrelated way. Characters are developed well. This series has everything except a mass printing for those who prefer paper and a movie for us all. I have a degree in English,  and honestly these are as well done as they get. Do not hesitate. Collect them all and join us in the silos. You will never be the same.

Hugh Howey is a name to remember and his hypnotic oeuvre WOOL: Omnibus, is surely a piece for everyone's library. The engrossing story keeps you guessing, wanting more, and incites intrigue into questioning the very values that we hold dear in our society in terms of normalcy. Hugh's vision of a post-apocalyptic world is truly one that is well thought out and unique to the genre and without giving away any spoilers, one that truly captivated me and left me with a feeling of hope for the new age of authors. You will not be able to put it down and if you do, perhaps you should be sent for cleaning! A great story and a great find from an excellent author that is destined for an explosion of exposure.

That's an aerial shot of 25 stars, ok? And that book, you think it's just another sci fi book? Ha! It's easily better than any of the books on the 2012 Arthur C. Clarke shortlist. Howey writes the technical stuff and the Great Concept stuff and the plot twists like it's nothing and unforgettable characters drive the stories. The buzz I get from reading Howey is like the buzz I got discovering Heinlein, who also did those things. But no, Howey's pacing is faster, his emotional range is wider and deeper, his ear for dialogue is Cohen-Brothers-worthy, and his plot twists are stunners. If you think it's impossible to imbue post-apocalyptic fiction with a sensawunda, I dare you to read this book.
So much more than I expected!! Kept me up all night! I cannot wait to find out what happens in Silo 17!

This book is compelling and rivoting.  The storyline is fascinating and plausible.  This is a very difficult book to put down, once you get going with it.  My only hesitation in giving it 5 stars is that the level of detail was sometimes a bit long-winded for me.  I like some detail...but balanced out with a lot of action when I am reading Sci-Fi... Authors who get it right for me: Joe Haledman (The Forever War) and most recently Patrick T. German (Progenitor: Palak and the Sky Gods). They both kept me turning pages quickly, not too mired down in any extraneous detail. Wool - Omnibus Edition is a great read, nonetheless and I will definitely seek out more books by this author.

I also stumbled upon the Wool-Omnibus by accident (I'm sure it showed up on my Amazon recommendations because I knit), but once inside the silo I couldn't leave; I didn't want to leave. The story grabbed me by both hands from the first chapter, and dragged me - gladly - through the levels. There was not a dull moment. The characters are well developed, the plot is three dimensional, and Howey is a talented story teller. Books 1-5 were all amazing, and I'm about half way through book 6 "First Shift," which is shaping up to be another fantastic story.  I love Wool, and as an avid knitter I enjoyed how bits of the fiber arts were subtly woven into the omnibus. Nice play on words.
I just want to say that I am very anxious to read the next book ( I just finish reading second shift).

Cutting my teeth on The Survivalist series by Jerry Ahern as a kid and playing Fallout 3 as an adult(kid), this story plays well with my interests - post apocalypse, survival, and the question of vault/bunker/silo existence for long periods.  John Rourke had the benefit of cryogenic sleep.  These folks went on living.  Incredible tale, character development, and how well the environment is detailed to paint a vivid mental image of the conditions.  I put it up there with Ender's Game and Starship Troopers (the book by Robert A. Heinlein, not the movie... please lend me some credit).  Great stuff, do yourself a favor and read it.  Can't wait for the movie!!!

More engaging than skillful. A premise like this is reiterative but successful and Wool does good by it. The writing has the unfortunate marks of self-publishing (the overwriting is particularly unforgivable), but only the tortured romances really harm the book, crumbling under the burden the plot places on them. Wool has every predictable flaw, in pacing, in emotional scope, but the truth is that if post-apocalyptic dystopic generation ships ping your interest, Wool is a satisfying take on those tropes. Its premise is intelligently constructed and the exploration in turns suspenseful and thoughtful, and the story that surrounds it is more than adequate.

Honestly I have always been a fan of fantasy/science-fiction because it presents a world that I have no chance of being a part of. I have read countless of these two genres and I will have to say this is without a doubt one of my favorites. I went out on a limb and bought this book without recommendation besides what o had seen on Amazon. From the first part onward I could not put it down, nothing I expected played out the way I saw it in my head. I would definitely recommend this book, it goes so much deeper then just another fiction book. Deception, deceit, and straight control play huge roles. I will be reading the rest of the series immediately

Of course, you have to suspend your sense of logic, and not probe too deeply into questions flitting about the edge of reality- Nonetheless, this series is a good read with some interesting characters. Surprisingly perhaps, the female characters in general exude more strength of character and are more appealing than the primary male characters, who tend to be relatively weak, borderline pathetic at times. The prequel 1st Shift was also worth reading- tho I would suggest reading Wool First. I look forward to reading further explorations of this world as they are published, while hoping there are fewer tears soaking the pages of future books.

I have never written a review.  However, I loved this book so I felt compelled to write a review so I could get the word out to others.  I enjoy post-apocalyptic fiction.  However, this story isn't as much about survival as it is about humanity.  It is a collection of short novelettes.  But, don't let this dissuade you from reading the Omnibus or each novelette individually.  It reads like one large novel.  I couldn't put the book down.  I could be heard gasping at many shocking and unexpected turns in the book.  Also, I'm an adult but my teenage son also loved the book and has already read the next book in the series "First Shift".

I can't begin to express properly how much I enjoyed the Omnibus collection of the Wool series. Juliette is my new favorite literary heroine, and I am officially a Wool-ite. Is that a term? Has it been invented yet? It should. What an impressive saga; so well written, original, and poignant. A tale of treachery, survival, bravery, desperation -- the human condition at its best, *and* at its worst that pulled me completely in didn't let go. I think differently about climbing stairs now. Differently about a lot of things. Hugh Howey has created something wonderful and I cannot wait to see what he has next in store for his readers.

I picked this book because of the ratings and the description that caught my attention.  I had high expectations of this book and it was met and exceeded.  It took me a few nights to finish this, about 2hrs/night cuz I am so busy like everyone else.  It was so hard not to think about this, literally all day.  I felt like I was in the silo watching the characters and wondering what would happen next.  It was so hard to detach and concentrate on my own daily activities.  This is the kind of book worth reading, worth my precious time.  Thanks Hugh Howey for taking me on such an unforgetable journey.  Hats off to you!

I came across several references to the Wool series over the last year but was always a little skeptical as it's just not my typical sort of read. Then when I saw the omnibus edition decided to check it. What a nice surprise it was! Howey really has a knack for capturing and keeping a reader's interest. Well developed characters with some depth, mysterious circumstances, challenges and conflict. All the ingredients are there but most importantly the writing skill and craft to make you want to keep reading. Give it a try - even if you're not a dyed in the wool (pun intended) post-apocalyptic/dystopian lit fan.

I admit to being somewhat biased against indie authors, but compilations like this are changing my mind. I found the book to be well realized, immersive, and well-paced. I like a good dystopia and found this well thought out and a real page turner. I ended up caring about the characters and felt that they were well drawn. I have now purchased more of Mr. Howey's work, and I look forward to his future stories as well. It isn't often that I find a new author whose work I want to follow; I'm pleased that I took a chance on this book! I recommend this for science fiction fans who enjoy suspenseful stories.

I loved this book, and neglected large portions of my life in order to keep reading.  A thoughtful premise, well-developed and appealing characters, and a plot that kept me intrigued until the last page. I've read so much fiction over the years, it is hard to find a new perspective that isn't predictable or cliched.  Howie manages it. At the end of the Kindle version, Hugh Howie says he reads all his Amazon reviews, so here's a message to you, Mr. Howie:  Thank you for writing this.  I'm your newest fan and am telling everyone I know about you.  Now stop messing around here and go write some more!

I really enjoyed the story line and hated to stop reading.  I even opened and read parts of Wool on the Kindle app on my phone while waiting for the kids to get out of school.  I can't think of another book that had me interested enough to switch from one device to another and back to keep reading.  I've passed the story on to my high school daughter as a must read this summer.  I love that the book is suitable for multiple age groups.  It was refreshing that it was a great story which wasn't marred by a lot of foul language and graphic sex scenes.  I will be recommending this series to friends.

Yes, I could put this book down.  In fact, I put it down several times.  I let my Kindle go dark because I could not bear to have it end -- it broke my heart to finish it.  So I made it last.  And I think about it.  This is a gritty story of the magic of the human spirit -- it is about the retaking of humanity and individuality and community. The author does not beat you over the head; he lets the characters take you on a journey of redemption.  The message is not preachy but it is timeless -- it could have been written in the 1400s or the 1900s or today.  I found it agnostically inspirational!

OK, so the title for this review gives it away.  I don't write reviews for most books I read but loved this one, definite 5 stars.  Very well written with good style and characterization.  Some very good twists along the way (no hints) that keep interest high.  At one point I was a little perplexed on the limited background for the situation (why were the Silos and toxins created) but it allowed for imagination to fill in.  I am a life-long sci-fi (not fantasy, creature-feature stuff) fan and this ranks in the top tenth or so.  My first book(s) from this author but will be looking for more.

Reading all the time and a lot of science fiction it was great to by accident find this writer. I read the 5 Wool books in one go on my Kindle. Looking at the price i first thought it would be bad, but I have to agree with the other reviewers, it is gripping, exciting and the use of language excellent. I have immediately bought the 4 Molly Fyd books and can almost not take the time to write this review.Hope there willl be more coming on the Wool series.It reminded me of the Logans' run series and Margaret Atwoods post apocalyptic books.My thanks to the other reviewers to recommend them.

I haven't read a book that's grabbed me like this in a few years. Usually when I read at night I start to fall asleep around 10. With Wool I had to force myself to put it down at midnight. The story is very original with lots of unexpected twists. Something that drives me nuts with other authors is when they don't explain things or leave vague situations. Usually because the author them self has no idea what happened. Hugh gives explanations about what's going on. They're brief but they add understanding to the story. This will appeal to any kind of sci-fi reader, and non sci-fi too.

This is the first time I have been impressed enough to review a book (series). First, I read alot! I tend to gravitate towards suspense, futuristic or apocalyptic type stories and this one definitely did not disappoint. However, even those who are not fans of the genre would enjoy it for the characters and the commentary on human nature. The author depicted the characters so the reader could empathize with their plight-even with those that were antagonists. It was not formulaic. I would think I had it all figured out and would be suprised time and again. Highly recommended!!

Wow, what a brilliant book. This has got to be one of the best PA/ Dystopian novels I've ever read and believe me I have read loads.... It's one of my favourite genres along with zombies.  5 Novellas seamlessly linked so easy to read. The world building is so richly detailed you can almost smell the stink of the oil and feel the vibrations of the machinery from the deeps. Really didn't want this to end, still not long to wait for the next book, really can't wait. If you love books in the PA/Dystopian genre, get this, you will never regret it. Can highly recommend it.

The first few pages of Wool left something to be desired, to the point where I almost stopped reading the sample. I'm very glad I didn't. This author has the potential to be one of the very best ever, and I've been reading science fiction for more than 50 years. There is no hype in this work, no attempt to create shallow excitement, no yanking the reader around. There is even limited science. Instead, the author develops the characters and builds his masterful story in a relentless, yet effortless fashion. "Wow", and its been a long time since I've said that.

If you haven't read a stitch of Howey's books, you may be wondering if you should buy the first wool or buy them all.  I'll skip to the chase, buy them all.  I bought them 5 days ago, and read them all, they are ridiculous.  Ridiculous because I've never in my life read a work of fiction as well-written and well-plotted as this book.  It's certainly a classic and it's only a year old.  I may in fact, also, be obsessed with Hugh Howey.  What a literary genius!  I hope he is handsomely rewarded and doesn't have to give all of his proceeds to our government...

As I read the first book, I thought it was going to go in a different direction than it ultimately did. With every book, I became more and more curious as to where it was going. Not your average predictable book. As a bonus, by book 5, it really got me thinking about the world we live in today (not that it was forced upon you by the author). The story line is great. It might have lagged a little in book 3 or 4 but I still enjoyed it as it's own story. I picked this up for 1.99 on a Kindle Daily Deal but it is certainly not a 1.99 read. Thank you Hugh Howey!

It's hard to point to just one thing that makes this book a must read. Not since Brave New World has an author offered such an eloquent story encompassing the trials and tribulations of one of many horrific, yet conceivable futures. Man's base nature is explored and challenged by societal constructs and treads the fine line between knowledge vs. survival for the common good. Absolutely fantastic and thought provoking read.  I look forward to reading more in this series, as well as exploring this author's body of work.  Thank you for this amazing story!

This is a must read for anyone who loves science fiction and even non science fiction lovers will find themselves converted. There are three so make sure you know you will be reading a trilogy. When I finished the third book I found myself depressed, I wasn't ready to leave the silo quite yet! Original plot, great writing and engaging characters all add up to the Silo Saga being put on the list of some of my favorite books of all time. Oh, I have heard them compared to The Hunger Games which were good but don't be fooled, these are way better!

I browse e-books constantly. I get so tired of amazing reviews that make you wonder, how did this book get published??? This is not one of those. I love Hugh's writing style, character development, & storyline. These days original stories in science fiction seem to be so fantastical they are hard to actually comprehend. This story is easy to follow, you don't have to imagine your some made up life form living in the vacuum of space. This book is just a very good story about one possible future, that's what makes it refreshing. Buy it :o)

Truly enjoyed this book, yet was highly disturbed by it during the entire time I read it. As all good science fiction novels accomplish, the story ends up not being about the science fiction -- the science fiction plays an important, but ultimately secondary role to the character development.  Good science fiction novels, IMO, develop fascinating characters who grow and change in their relationship to the science fiction background they find themselves in.  Well worth the time and effort to read, you will not be disappointed.

I knew I had to read Wool when my brother, an avid reader, told me it was the best book he had read in years. I tried to get it from the library, but with only one copy in circulation and a hold going back some 30 patrons,I ended up reading all of the books on my Kindle in just two days- and ruining my bedtime in the process. Kudos to Hugh Howey for an inventive dystopian that leaves you begging for a follow up! (Howey, you said you read ALL the reviews, so please continue with Silo 17....that Jimmy is interesting!)

With little to go on I chose this book because Amazon recommended it. As a long time SciFi reader/buyer I figured they had a pretty good idea what I liked. For a first time author or a veteran for that matter, he knew what strings to pull. I thought I had read every type of plot, but with his character development, this seemed new. Actually I can't remember a story line quite like this. Highly recommended. I have never reviewed anything before, but thought this was worth the trouble. Hope he writes more soon.

I really enjoyed this book.  There were times I could not read fast enough to find out what happened to the character.  Bernard was a complex character, evil at most times, but seemed sad about his fate when he was talking to Lukas heart to heart below.  But regretfully carried out the Plan.  These are the kind of stories you don't want to end and want to see how their lives unfold in the future.  What about Solo and the kids in silo 17?  Will they be brought back to silo 18.  I guess that's for another book.

This book was GOOD.  I am not a clever reviewer, so look elsewhere for literary critique...  I read to be entertained intelligently- this book did that and then some.  I couldn't put it down.  The characters were the type that you invest in, the story had enough mystery to make it a page turner, there were just the right amount of details.  And of course, I love PAF.  And this is PAF done just right.  I can't wait to read more about the silos. Thanks to the author for writing outside the box, job well done.

Other reviewers have chimed in, so I won't be verbose. I agree with almost everything positive said! The story grabs you from the start, and just when you think you have figured out the next turn, the next logical development takes you by surprise! The surprises grow out of the information presented, so it's not like 'oh suddenly a ufo appears and gives someone super powers.' No, these surprises build out of the characters and the environment, and make perfect sense. And the ending is great! I want more!

I haven't read much science fiction in the past and I am unsure that I could recreate the google search that led me to this book but I was  certainly pleased. As soon as I started reading about Sheriff Holston I became intrigued. I felt like a kid staying up late and telling myself, "One more chapter, then I'm going to bed". Just bought part 6 for my kindle and I am ready to find out more. Thank you for this series. I will certainly be reading more of Hugh Howey's books as well as other science fiction.

I really enjoyed reading this series of books compiled into one purchase.  The story was a bit slow for me at first, but once I became invested in the characters and plot, I could hardly put it down.  I thought that the author interview at the end of the book was hilarious.  I have read another book by the same author (Book 1 in the Molly Fyde Series) and was not disappointed.  I have purchased several other books by Hugh Howey and eagerly look forward to reading them all.  Check him out at [...].

The unexpected part was the price, the treasure part was how long this book hung around my thoughts. It begins so simply that you don't really think you will keep reading, maybe it's a little elementary... But the next time you come up for air, notice it's now dark outside, oh gee what time is it, really? And just like that, you're fully hooked. The five books collected in the Omnibus went by much too quickly, and I'm now starting on First Shift-Legacy. Some reviews say it's better? We'll see..

Let me start out by saying i have never written a review before but I needed to find a way to let the author and Amazon know how much i enjoyed these stories. I read alot.  I am 63 and over the years have read many, many Sci-Fi books as well as others.  I loved the Omnibus and didnt want to put it down.  What a great movie this would make.  I just want to read more about this world and these people.  I will read all of the authors other books as well.  Thank you for the great story.

I had read all of the positive reviews on this book prior to getting it, but I have to admit, I am always a bit leery of post-apocalyptic novels - they really can go either way, and it tends to be the wrong way.  Wool, however, was absolutely amazing.  I was pulled into the story immediately, and it never let me go.  I absolutely could not put it down.  It was extremely well written, engaging, and provided a very interesting perspective on basic human psychology.  I loved it!

It has been a while since I read a story that made me not want to put it down. I really had a tough time going to work knowing there was more to read. They line was well thought out and used one of my favorite writing devices where you see one story line that is told from multiple perspectives. Like in Fifth Element where Zorg and Lelu are telling the same story about the stones. I had a wonderful time reading this and I am looking forward to reading more soon. Thanks.

I've been an avid reader my whole life.  Amazon and Kindle have taken me to the next level.  Searching Amazon for inexpensive fodder for my reading habit, I stumbled across Wool.  Hugh Howey?  Never heard of him.  The title caught my interest, the reviews convinced me to read it and I cannot express how much pleasure I derived from the rarest form of reading - a book you can't put down.  Unfortunately, now I've got a Hugh Howey habit along with my other obsessions.

I really am hoping that there is another Wool novel because this story needs to continue.  While the novel ends in a satisfying way the whole story becomes larger and larger as it is unveiled another book or two could easily be written.  The characters are well developed and are placed in a setting that becomes more believable over the course of the book.  I would high recommend this book and have already emailed several friends that they should pick up a copy.

I purchased this omnibus edition because of the great reviews on Amazon and was definitely not disappointed.  This is the best new SF I have read in a long time - intriguing story, great characters, I just couldn't put it down until finished.  Have since been given a Kindle and have now read the prequel Shift Series, also highly recommended, these novellas provide further insights into the story of the Silos.  Looking forward to reading more from this author.

It is twenty to two in the morning, just finished Wool omnibus.  Recommended to me by a friend.  Have not been able to stop reading this series.  Eating cereal - reading Wool, walking through the halls - reading Wool, laying awake in bed - Wool, Wool, Wool!  Have recommended and will continue to recommend.  Thank you Hugh for a wonderfully crafted story.  Bloody brilliant.  I am on a book high right now.  Dreading the inevitable symptoms of Wool withdrawal.

This book was recommended because I read The Martian and I have to say that I am so happy that I decided to purchase this book. It was so well written from the very beginning. You feel like you are there in the silo, walking the steps, looking out at a devastated wasteland. I wanted to know why they were there, what is out there, what happened to our world. Fabulous characters that you get to know in short time, keep you coming back for more. Great read!

Thought this was a great sci-fi read. I am normally not a huge sci-fi reader, but I have read many of the classics, and I thought this one ranked right up there with 1984, Brave New World, Ender's Game, etc. It is very engaging, although the beginning moves a bit slowly. Once you get into the first couple of chapters, I guarantee you will be hooked. Howey always makes you think you know where he is going with this story, but I bet it will surprise you!

What a great series! I was hooked immediately and then it just kept getting better. While the storytelling is excellent, it was more so the thought-provoking nature of the story that was so riveting. It makes you ponder a lot of "what-if's" & makes you question if the guys you thought were the "bad guys" aren't actually the good guys, etc. I enjoyed the suspense aspect as well, and the characters you get attached to along the way. Highly recommend!!

I would give very few books that I have read five stars, but this one is worthy. Not only does the story have some surprising twists to it, but the author is quite a good writer, describing little details that make you feel as though you are standing right there with the characters. The story had good character development and was mysteriously intriguing like the TV series "Lost" except the book had  real answers to the mysteries. Bravo Mr. Howey.

Seriously, I haven't been drawn into a world like this since I read 'Hyperion' back in the day. The viceral connection to the characters, the over turning of my expectations, loved it. Maybe Bernard could be a little less villain-y, with less moustache twirling, and indeed by the end he is much more fleshed out and you can at least see his point of view. I just found Howey, and now I'm kind of upset he didn't get a Nebula nomination last year.

This is the first time I have ever written a review - I usually can't be bothered but what a find this book was! I loved it! Well written, excellent depth to the characters, amazing story-line - and really inexpesive considering the length and un-put-down-abilty of this book. I am a lover of apocalypse-type novels and this ticked every box for me. I will definatly be reading more by this author. If I could have given it 6 stars I would have.

While not as strong on character development as I usually prefer in my reading, the premise of this story grabbed me immediately, and when it was over, I wanted more. Good science-fiction has always carried a political message and this one is no different; however, the author managed to prevent the politics from taking over the story. I wanted more...imagine my joy at having just discovered Book 6! Hi-ho, hi-ho, it's back to the silos I go!

This series was absolutely fantastic.  Each story congruent and interesting. Couldn't put it down.  I am really looking forward to next story and have really found myself wondering about the future of these characters.  In the past I found it difficult to identify with characters in short stories but these were so wonderfully portrayed that they made me buy stock in each of them.  Buy this book, recommend this book.  This is a great read!

Loved, loved, loved this book.  I now have a new addition to my very short list of favorite authors.  Well written, characters I cared about, scenarios I worried about...this book had it all.  I lost a lot of sleep over this book since I do most of my reading at night before bed; I could never find a good place to stop!  I wonder how long it will be before someone turns this book in to a big screen hit, or better yet, a stellar TV series.

As other reviews mention, Howey is a true master of pace and world building.  The world of Wool absorbed me and I had a hard time putting the book down, which in my case is not an easy feat.  The information is delightfully released, never too early but done in such an elegant way I never felt it was held back from the reader to achieve "Sixth Sense" effect.  I highly recommend Howey's Wool and will definitely buy his next book.

Wow.  Just finished this last night and I have to say it's been a while since I've read something this enjoyable.  Usually, there are places here and there in a book that are a little slow, or cumbersome, or confusing.  Not so this one, however.  It was a pleasure to read from cover to cover.  You won't be sorry picking this one up except if you are trying to get sleep and have this on your nightstand--you will hate putting it down!

Each of these short books could stand on their own.  I absolutely loved getting to know a set of characters in each book.  And even though the first book was quite short there was a lot of development in that time.  And then each book built off the previous without having to do any glaringly annoying recaps.  I also must say the writing was beautifully done and each book had an ending that made me think.  I definitely recommend it.

Are you dying for a science fiction storyline with believable human characters, where the outcomes are not predictable and the science is sound? If you like Jack McDevitt's approach- where ordinary people act in extraordinary settings- you will love these books. So refreshing to read some solid science fiction and not be weighed down with fantasy overtones and five million alien species. Thoroughly enjoyable and highly recommended.

All I can say is, this is the first book I've read that ever prompted me to write a review. To be honest, I was not expecting much from this book, as the past few years in sci-fi literature has been letting me down. But After reading the first chapter, I felt like I was reading one of the classics. My only disappointment - I read the omnibus and first shift way too fast- now I have to wait for the next in the series to come out!

Honestly, this story already has over 2,000 5-star reviews. How many more do you need? If one more will help, I absolutely recommend reading Wool Omnibus. The story is incredibly unique with characters and plots that made my heart pound, made my brain work overtime on the fantastic puzzles, and made me go through a teenage girl-esque range of emotions. I just can't imagine that whoever reads this won't love it. Impossible!

On a toxic, ruined planet, ancient survivors build an underground silo where remnants of humanity survive for centuries. But there are closely guarded secrets that only a few know. When Jules, a brilliant mechanic from the "down deep" starts connecting the dots, the action takes off.

Yes, I am late to the party. But had to have my share of the conversation. Superior writing: clear, concise, not a careless word written. Engaging from start to finish. Thank the lawd I bought the series in one go-- as they were inhaled like chips-- one after another! My neglected family will be relieved that I can now get back to cooking and cleaning and other mundane tasks. Please someone, put this on the Big Screen.

I bought this book based on the number of high level reviews, and I can't say enough, I am not sorry I did - this is one of the most riveting, well written and crafted stories I've read in a long time.  Almost anything I say may give away something of the story, so I'll just recommend - read the first two books before coming to any judgement - then you will be hooked. Thank you Mr. Howey for an excellent piece of work.

Could go on and on about how exceptional this series is! Great concept that allows for spot on looks into human nature. Exceptional storytelling and perfect pacing, especially in 1 & 2! Mature writing that had me spellbound the whole time. Still in awe that Mr. Howey is a new writer! Classic stories that will stand the test of time. Best of all, there's more to come with the Shift series! Bring on the movie/TV series!

What a great sci fi!  I haven't read such an original, captivating  sci fi in a long time, and I have been reading sci fi for almost 50 years.  The characterization was great, the world setting was unique and fully developed, the plot pulled you right along.  I was a little hesitant when my book reader said 1257 pages...it could have been twice as long.  Don't wait- you will love Wool!  Let's hope there is a sequel.

Short and sweet review...this is easily one of the best books I've read in awhile. It's fresh, well written, and a book I just couldn't put down. I've lost plenty of sleep this week from reading it well past when I should have already been in bed. I'm glad it's gotten so many good reviews or else I might have skimmed over it and totally missed out. The only thing I wish is that there were more books on the horizon.

How long does it really take to climb stairs?  Seriously.  I work in a 40 story building and people (albeit not me) go up and down the building in an hour or so.  Why does it take these folks a week to climb 50 stories?  Also, how are these folks getting air in the bottom stories?  An oil well at the bottom?  Different cultures between stories?  A murderous IT Department?  Nothing about the story makes much sense.

Picked this up on the Kindle and loved it. Howey has created a rich world filled with believable and sympathetic characters to guide you. I don't want to spoil anything, but I will say that it's rare to find a writer who can both craft solid characters and a truly creative "what if?" I really recommend it. Hell, I'm buying a copy for a few friends who love Science Fiction. Definitely see this as a future classic.

I have read MORE than my share of dystopian fiction. I really thought that there could not possibly be another take on it. Then my friend recommended WOOL. Boy was I wrong. This book is so, so good. You think you have it figured out and then you are wrong. And then you are wrong again. The characters are real and the story is heart breaking. You will find yourself cheering and ready to devour the next one!!!

Howey created a masterpiece. Off of an original short story. It's brilliant. The first part is amazing, second part was a little slow for me, but then it picks up and I literally had to put the book down multiple times and just say "holy crap" because a twist was so brilliantly executed I was just sitting their reeling. Howey really has a great great work here and I cannot wait to read more from him.

I'm not usually a fan of sci-fi, but I really enjoyed WOOL. It has been years since I've been so engrossed with a book that I couldn't stop reading it. Hugh Howey creates a vivid portrayal of life in a massive underground bunker. This series explores many aspects of human nature in an unimaginable environment. Since reading WOOL I have read several of his other books and plan on continuing to do so.

I loved this book (series?) I had thought the dystopian society genre was written out, but nope! I couldn't put it down and can't wait to start the Silo series.  Thanks for the low price!  This is a well-written book with adequate detail without pages of what should come from the reader's imagination.  I was attached to the characters and thinking about them when I wasn't reading it.  Love that!

I bought this on a whim on a weekend road trip along with the classic "Enders Game" series.  This was easily as engrossing and interesting.. I absorbed it continuously over the weekend to the dismay of my husband and son.  I literally could not put it down.  Great characters, great story.  you won't be disappointed.  Fingers crossed that Hugh's other books are as good as I am off to buy another.

As someone who normally does not read science fiction, I still put WOOL as one of the best books of the decade.  Incredible story that will let your mind imagine a new world and picture yourself in it. At first readers will take pride in their superior knowledge over the characters in the WOOL silos, but eventually you begin to wonder if perhaps similar ignorance controls our own world as well.
